characters: EXT LAKE SIDE HIGH SCHOOL PARTY
HOLD A FEW SECONDS AND THEN FADE IN

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSE UP on a single BEAD OF SWEAT. The skin it belongs to is out of focus.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What have you learned from this and how has it prepared you for the future?” The lone bead of sweat begins its slow descent. RACK FOCUS on the bead of sweat to REVEAL the “skin” is actually a beer bottle. And then we SLOWLY PULL BACK to show who the voice and beer belong to: SUTTER KEELY, 18, boyishly handsome, killer smile. He takes a swig of the beer, staring at a college application on his computer. As he thinks about the answer, we get a glimpse of Sutter’s room. A small desk. A twin bed. Clothes on the floor. Decorations include a baseball pennant from some minor league team and a framed photo of the Rat Pack. BACK ON Sutter, staring down the application. An idea comes to him. He starts to type.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Dear... Dean of Admissions... My name is Sutter Keely and up until yesterday I had the best fucking girlfriend in the world.” INT CASSIDY’S LIVING ROOM - DAY CASSIDY (18, Scandinavian blonde, pure soft skin, hot) takes off her shirt, revealing her voluptuous body. She’s on top of Sutter, who lies on his back on the floor. Sutter looks up at her, can’t believe how lucky he is. INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - SAME Sutter types.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I know I probably shouldn’t say “fuck” right there but I’m sorry, I have to.  INT CASSIDY’S LIVING ROOM - DAY Naked, Cassidy grinds on Sutter. Getting into it. Her eyes are closed. She’s in control.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: She’s tremendous. High definition. And so damn beautifully fat. Like, in a good way. You know what I mean? Immaculate proportions. I dated Cassidy two months longer than anyone else. It was magic. INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - SAME Sutter stops typing. Takes another drink. Mulls something over.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Shit. I’m getting ahead of myself. Let’s start at the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: EXT CONVENIENCE STORE PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: Sutter pulls into the parking lot of a suburban strip mall off the highway. There’s a vast openness in every direction. The horizon unsettlingly far away.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Like all great stories, mine begins with a breakfast burrito... Sutter gets out of his car and notices, in front of the store, a YOUNG KID (8), hands in his pockets, kicking a rock.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hey little man, you ok? (no answer) Shouldn’t you be in school or something? The Kid shrugs. Sutter nods to him as he walks:

dialogues.speaker: INT CONVENIENCE STORE
dialogues.text: Sutter goes to the soft drink counter and pours himself a Big Gulp of 7UP. The Kid follows him inside. As the Clerk rings Sutter up, the Kid sheepishly tugs on his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG KID
dialogues.text: Can I borrow a dollar?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What do you need a dollar for?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG KID
dialogues.text: Three Musketeers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How bout a tasty breakfast burrito? On me.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG KID
dialogues.text: And a Three Musketeers?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (laughs; to the Clerk) You heard him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT CONVENIENCE STORE
dialogues.text: Sutter and the Kid exit the store. Sutter has his Big Gulp. Kid has his breakfast. Sutter is about to walk away when he realizes -- this Kid isn’t going anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Granted I was late to pick up Cass for school. But I couldn’t just leave him on the side of the road, could I? INT SUTTER’'S CAR - MOMENTS LATER Sutter drives and Walter sits next to him. Barren branches on the tree-lined streets.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: So where to my good man?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Florida.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (surprised) Florida?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I'm going to see my Dad. This effects Sutter, who turns to look at the Kid.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What’s, uh, what’s he doing there?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: He was fighting a lot. With my Mom. She made him leave us.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: No shit, dude! High five! (off his confused look) Same thing happened to me and my sister!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-hmm. I was 8 or 9. Just like you. My Dad was the best... Sutter takes a drink from his Big Gulp. His heart breaking for this kid.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You're really going, huh? Walter nods.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Well good for you, kid. I think that’s very brave. (beat) Got any money? (he doesn’t) Cash? Credit cards...? Nothing like that? You know Florida’s pretty far, right? What if you get hungry? (he shrugs) Well you’re gonna need food, aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I could hunt it.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Ha. That’s true. You could hunt it. You got a gun? Knife? Fishing rod, at least...?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I have a baseball bat.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: That could work! Where’s your bat?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It’s at home.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hmm. You know what I think? I think maybe we should go get your bat.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: But we can’t. My mom is there.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What if I talk to her? Explain the situation.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you’re with the Sutterman. (takes a big drink) Don’t you worry bout a thing.

dialogues.speaker: EXT WALTER'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Sutter knocks. WALTER'S MOM (late 20s, pretty) opens it.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S MOM
dialogues.text: Walter!? What are you doing out of school?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Pardon me, ma’am, but, uh, Walter’s sort of upset. The Woman looks at Walter who looks away. At which point she looks at the Big Gulp, then back up at Sutter.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S MOM
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: My name’s Sutter Keely. I found him over at the 7/11.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER'S MOM
dialogues.text: (beat; smells something) Have you been drinking?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Uh, no ma’am. (already backing away) Just thought you might like your kid back, that’s all. I’m gonna go now. And once at his car:

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: By the way... you are just stunning to look at. The Woman eyes Sutter one last beat, then walks inside, angrily slamming the door behind her. Sutter shakes his head -- the nerve of some people -- gets in his car.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Moms... what can I tell ya? INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - AGAIN ANGLE ON a_framed picture by his bedside, showing Sutter (5) on the shoulders of a HANDSOME MAN, his father. Back on Sutter, at his desk, as he continues typing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I enjoy a drink from time to time. For me, it’s like a hobby.

dialogues.speaker: EXT HIGH SCHOOL PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: Sutter parks his Mitsubishi Lancer. He takes a swig from a flask before walking into school.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A pleasant diversion from all the annoying responsibilities that come with being a kid.

dialogues.speaker: EXT HIGH SCHOOL
dialogues.text: The class runs laps around the track. We see Sutter in the middle of the pack running backwards, smiling. Kids crack up at his antics.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Gym class. INT SUTTER’'S DINING ROOM - NIGHT Sutter’s family sits at the table. Mom MARY, sister HOLLY, Holly’s husband JOE. The family says “Grace” and with their eyes closed, Sutter seizes the opportunity for a quick drink.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Xmas Dinner with my family. INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - AGAIN

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: This essay. Sutter takes another sip. Continues.

dialogues.speaker: EXT HOUSE PARTY
dialogues.text: Sutter reveals, from beneath his T-shirt, a keg tap. PARTYGOERS cheer and applaud. Sutter is the man.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: People talk about the dangers of drinking, how harmful it is Nobody talks about the good stuff. How great it feels. How much fun it can be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERIES OF SHOTS: Sutter does shots with friends, including Cassidy. - Sutter standing up on a couch leading the room in a song.  - Sutter diving into a pool fully clothed. Partygoers follow him in. Over which we hear:

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When I’m drinking, it’s like I can see another dimension to the world. Words and ideas I never knew I had come flying out of me. I’m funny, compassionate, in love with everything. INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - AGAIN Sutter typing.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Besides, it’s not like I’m some toothless derelict drinking by himself late at night. I’m 18. This is what I’m supposed to be doing. Sutter takes another swig. Confident now. He continues: EXT CASSIDY’S HOUSE - DAY Sutter knocks on the door. No answer. He can hear loud, angry music blaring from inside.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So meanwhile, thanks to Walter, I’m late to pick my girlfriend up for school. Sutter calls for her. Nothing. Knocks again. Still nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Shit. Sutter walks around back. He sizes up the large tree next to the house. Takes a sip from his cup. QUICK JUMP CUTS of SUTTER: - climbing the tree, Big Gulp in hand - leaping to the roof, Big Gulp in his teeth - lunging for the Big Gulp and losing his grip on the roof - hanging from the gutter when Cassidy appears at the window:

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Sutter?!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hey gorgeous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you -- ? The gutter rips from the side of the house, taking Sutter down with it. He lands hard on his tailbone with a yelp. Cassidy stands over him, arms crossed, livid. INT CASSIDY’S LIVING ROOM - MINUTES LATER Sutter sits on the couch, rubbing his injuries. Cassidy paces as she reprimands Sutter.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Do you even remember what we talked about?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (no idea) Of... course I do. SUTTER’S VOICE I had absolutely no idea what she’s talking about. Cassidy’s lips move as she continues her rant but all we hear is: SUTTER’S VOICE She’s always saying something or other and I try to listen, honest to God, but I mean... look at her.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Cause it’s the last time I’m gonna say it.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I...’m with you. 100 percent.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Promise?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Cross my heart, hope to die. (beat) Now how bout a kiss? Cassidy tries to stay mad at Sutter but it’s virtually impossible. He throws her that smile and her resolve crumbles. They quickly undress and start getting into it. Sutter looks up at her. Can’t believe how lucky he is.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What can I say, I’m a romantic. I am in love with the feminine species. It’s a shame you only get to pick one, but since that’s the rule, I was very grateful for the one I had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home of the Plainsmen.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well the next day, it all went to shit. A bell rings, signaling the end of the day. Kids spill out of the building and head in all directions.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You remember high school. Everyone’s got their thing. ANGLE ON a tough-looking jock with a varsity jacket.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Denver Quigley, his thing is sports. ANGLE ON a long-haired kid in a back Jim Morrison shirt.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Josh Green. Biggest Doors fan in the state. ANGLE ON Sutter, who stands by the entrance with his best friend RICKY (18, undersized, Indian-American). Sutter points to a girl. Ricky shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My best friend Ricky... he’s Indian. Sutter points to another. Again, Ricky rejects.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And me, my thing is making people feel good. I’m the fun guy. Just like my dad. There’s no feeling down when ol’ Sutter's around.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Colleen Marshall?

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Way too tall. I’d look like her son.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: That’s it. I’m tired of your excuses. I say, “tonight’s the night.”

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: What night?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: The night I get you some action.  10. INT/EXT SUTTER’S CAR - DOWNTOWN STREET - NIGHT Cars zoom by as Sutter and Ricky drive extra slow with the windows down, scoping left and right for something or someone to perk up the evening. It may be “Downtown” but there’s little to do. Ricky pulls out a blaze and lights it. Sutter sips from his Big Gulp.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: I don’t know about this.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Relax. From behind the car, headlights flash. Sutter squints through the rearview. See two girls waving excitedly. Sutter smiles. RICKY (CONT’D) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Potential. Sutter pulls into a shopping plaza. The girls’ car pulls up alongside him. The driver is BETHANY, the passenger TARA.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hi Tara. Bethany.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: Just the man I was looking for. Know where we can score some beers?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (does he ever) Step into my office ladies. Sutter gets out and gestures to the back of his car. He pops the trunk, revealing that he’s turned the trunk into a cooler -- it’s filled to the brim with ice and beer.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: My hero.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Bethany, you know Ricky don’t you? Ricky awkwardly waves. Bethany awkwardly waves back.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: So what’s your plan for tonight?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (laughs) Plans? You know me better than that. I don’t plan, I improvise.  11. Sutter looks around.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You guys up for a boat ride? Off their faces we...

dialogues.speaker: EXT CANALS
dialogues.text: A canal runs between two long rows of buildings like a river at the bottom of a canyon. Sutter helps Ricky and Bethany get on the boat.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It takes me all of 30 seconds to get them alone.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Oh shit. I left my wallet in the car.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: I have enough --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (hinting) No dude, don’t worry about it. You guys go ahead. I’1l run back and get it. (to Tara) You’1ll come with me, right?

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: Sure. As the boat floats away Sutter winks at Ricky, who’s now “trapped” on the boat with Bethany.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (calling after them) See you guys in a bit. Ricky looks at Bethany and can only shrug. Back on land:

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Want some ice cream?

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: I thought you lost your wallet.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (pulls it out of his pocket) Hey, whaddaya know?

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: You're terrible.  12.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: They make a cute couple, don’t they? INT SUTTER’S CAR - LATER Sutter and Tara are drinking. A baseball game plays on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: TARA
dialogues.text: I can’t wait to get out of this place. Can we put on some music or something?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: No I like this. Tara thinks this strange but doesn’t say so. It’s at this point when a car comes careening into the parking lot. Sutter and Tara turn. Cassidy storms out of the car. Furious.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (upbeat) Hey Cass --

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Can I speak to you in private please? Sutter goes to give Cass a hug but she pushes him off.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Kendra said she saw you with Tara. I didn’t believe her.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah, the girls wanted some beers so--

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: I asked you to do one thing for me. One. And you still couldn’t do it.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What are you so mad about? What thing?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: I asked you to put someone else’s feelings before your own. For once in your life!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Wait a sec. That is what I’m doing!

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Oh please --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: It’s the truth! Ask Ricky. I’m just here to --  13.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: You're the most selfish person I’ve ever met.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Are you hearing me? I’m doing this for Ricky. I’m completely unselfish. Cassidy sees Tara in the car, beer in hand. Tara looks away, like she knows she was doing something wrong.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: You’re a lost cause, Sutter.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Cass, you gotta believe me --

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. No. We’re done.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Cassidy! It’s too late. She gets in the car and drives off. Sutter stands there. Buzzed enough to not be upset. Yet.

dialogues.speaker: EXT SCHOOL PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: We're back with Sutter. He looks up from the page. Thinks for a moment, and then continues writing:

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A misunderstanding. No big deal. She’d come around, right? Well listen to this. Fucking last night... INT SUTTER’S CAR - AGAIN Sutter drives crosstown, the sound of a baseball announcer again fills the car. He nips from the flask.

dialogues.speaker: EXT SUBURBAN CUL DE SAC
dialogues.text: A nicer neighborhood. There’s nowhere for Sutter to park so he decides, fuck it, he’s double parking. Sutter gets out and walks towards the biggest house on the block. There’s a party going on inside. En route to the front door, he plucks a handful of flowers from a neighbor's garden.

dialogues.speaker: INT HOUSE PARTY
dialogues.text: Flowers in hand, Sutter wanders through the place looking for Cassidy. The house is huge and expensively decorated. Occasional partygoers high-five him on the way but he’s in no mood to be social right now. And then he sees her. Sitting on the couch, playing with the hair of MARCUS WEST (18, tall, lanky, athletic).  14.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Well this is unexpected. Cass and Marcus turn. Cassidy is surprised to see him.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? Knowing he’s lost her, Sutter hides the flowers behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You got a haircut.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Yeah I... seemed like a good time for a change.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Goddamn stunning, that haircut.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Are you drunk or something?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Well if drunk equals A, and something equals B, let’s just say the answer is... definitely not B. Marcus looks at Sutter with a touch of sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Look man, I know this is awkward. Maybe we should talk outside--

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Marcus West! Speaking to me?! What an honor!

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Oh God, Sutter...

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Come on man, let’s go out to my car.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Thank you excellency, but that won’t be necessary. I am a fair-minded individual who thoroughly understands the meaning of the phrase ‘kicked to the curb.’ Sutter bows, struggling to keep his balance. Then backs away.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Sutter...  15.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I bid you both a pleasant evening. Marcus wants to stop Sutter from leaving but Cassidy puts her arm out.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Let him go. He drives better that way.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (still backing away) Thanks for the vote of confidence, beautiful! You are the most understanding woman... in everything but love. Arrivederci! Sutter turns with a flourish and stumbles away. INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - AGAIN Sutter finishes the essay in a flurry.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Unbelievable, isn’t it? You want hardship, misfortune, well there you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Sutter getting dressed for the evening. - Sutter drinking some more.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A weaker-minded individual would get depressed. Sit in his room, maybe cry about it. Not this guy. Not Sutter Keely. Don’t count me out just yet, Dean of Admissions. It’s another day, and the night is just getting started. So forget Cassidy, forget exams, forget these pointless college apps. Fuck the past, fuck the future. all that matters is the here and now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Sutter looking at himself in the mirror, psyching himself up for the night ahead.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’m Sutter Keely and I say... it’s time to be alive. And with that, on Sutter smiling: Music up: The Walkmen/ “The Rat”  16. INT SUTTER’S CAR - NIGHT Music continues over Sutter driving, two hands on the wheel. Drumming a bit to the loud music. Psyching himself up for a good night. (Note: when Sutter is drinking, his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: world is vibrant, sharp, rich in color. It won’t always be this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Sutter gets turned away by a BOUNCER. Pretends it doesn’t bother him. - Sutter ambles along down the promenade. Takes a nip at his flask. All around him, YOUNG COUPLES stroll past. He tips his imaginary hat at a BUSKER playing acoustic guitar on the street. - Sutter turned away from another bar. Now getting frustrated. Sees a sign for a bar across the way and the best part -- no bouncer.

dialogues.speaker: INT BAR
dialogues.text: In comes Sutter. The place is crowded. As luck would have it, he spots a table full of COLLEGE GIRLS. Decides to approach.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Ladies... I’m 18 years old and I just got dumped by my girlfriend. Will someone, anyone, please have a drink with me? A beat. The Girls are delighted to meet him! - Sutter and the Girls do a round of shots. Then another. They love this kid. - Sutter dances between two of the Girls. They play with his hair, pinch his cheeks. Innocent fun.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BAR
dialogues.text: Sutter and the Girls are leaving. We quickly realize they’re not leaving together. As they walk away Sutter yells after them.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I love you! The Girls look back and laugh -- he’s so cute.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I love everyone! But the Girls keep walking.  17. INT SUTTER’S CAR - LATER Cruising - windows down, wind in his face, radio on. Drunk and feeling much better now.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (yelling out the window) You are holy! You are beautiful! Down with the king! Down with the motherfucking-- SMASHCUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Um... hello... A face. Or, at least, a head. Female. Completely in shadow from the bright morning sun and thus impossible to make out. Sutter, who has clearly spent the night passed out on the ground, looks up, disoriented. Puts his hand up to see who it is. And we see her. Sutter’s age but looking younger. Pale with freckles and glasses. Her hair is strawberry blonde and her eyes the color of a public swimming pool. Her name is AIMEE FINECKY.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You're alive. When she talks it’s like she just discovered her voice.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I thought maybe you were dead. Sutter blinks a few times.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I don’t think I’m dead... Where the hell am I?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You're in the middle of a yard. Do you know who lives here? Sutter sits up. Looks at the ugly pink little house.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Jesus, I must have gone to sleep. Hey, where’s my car?  18.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Is it one of those? Sutter looks at the nearby parked cars. Can’t find his anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Maybe I parked it at home and just went for a walk.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You don’t live in this neighborhood. Do you, Sutter?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You know my name?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: We go to the same school... You wouldn’t remember me.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: No... of course I do. You’re um...

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Aimee. Aimee Finecky.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Right. Aimee. I was about to say that. (standing) What time is it, Aimee?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: 6am.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Are you coming back from a party or something?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I’m on my paper route. She motions to the white pickup truck that’s pulled over. We see the back is filled with papers.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: It’s really my mom’s paper route but she went to the casino last night with my step-dad. She hasn’t come back yet.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You need some help?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I can manage.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: No I’ll help you.  19.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Aimee, you’re driving round the neighborhood, I gotta find my car. I’m thinking we can help each other out. Whaddaya say? Off her look: INT AIMEE’S CAR - LATER Aimee drives and Sutter throws papers while looking for his car. It takes a few throws until Sutter gets the hang of it.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I didn’t realize newspaper throwing was such big business. You must reel in some cash.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: My mom does.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What, and you get nothing?!

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I get an allowance.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: An allowance? That doesn’t sound fair. I mean, You do all the work.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Well yeah but... she pays the bills... most of them.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Most of them?! Aimee, she’s your mom! (off her shrug) Aw man, I don’t know. Sounds to me like a pretty raw deal, this paper route. If I were you, I’d say something. A sad smile comes over her face. Standing up for herself is the last thing Aimee ever does. Sutter feels bad for her, decides to change the subject. Throwing more papers:

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I’m getting the hang of this, aren’t I?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You're a natural.  20.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Back in Little League, You should have seen me. I had this booming arm. Here. Watch this. (throws right on target) Look at that! Are you impressed?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Very.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I had the gift, Aimee. That’s what my Dad used to say. Probably could have gone pro if I stuck with it.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: So what happened?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you stick with it? Sutter doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hey look! There it is! Sutter’s Mitsubishi is parked sideways in the middle of a lawn. Aimee pulls over.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: What’s it doing on the lawn?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: That is a very good question. Aimee assumes that now the car has been spotted Sutter will take off.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Well... thanks again. For helping me.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (motioning to all the papers) Whaddaya mean? We’re not done yet!

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You don’t have to --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hey it’s the least I can do. Besides, I’m enjoying myself. Let’s keep going. The light flips back on in her eyes.  21.

dialogues.speaker: OK
dialogues.text: (beat) Should you move your car first?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Yes. Good idea. Sutter jumps out to move his car. Aimee waits. Smiles. INT AIMEE’S CAR - LATER Now they're having fun delivering the papers.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Fire the torpedo, Special Agent Danger!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Aye aye, Captain! Sutter launches another paper. It lands right on the doorstep.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (explosion sound effect) Direct shot! They share a laugh. It’s nice. - LATER. Paper route over.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: We make a good team, don’t we?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Sutter catches the look on Aimee’s face. She’s beaming.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You know what, Aimee Finecky? I had a pretty rotten night last night until you came along. We should get lunch sometime.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: How bout Monday?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Oh...k Monday it is. Where should we meet?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: The cafeteria?  22.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Why not! We can relive our greatest triumphs of newspaper delivery! Aimee smiles at him. It’s nerdy but endearing.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: See you Monday, Captain. With that, he’s off. Feeling pretty good about it too. INT SUTTER’S HOME - LATER It’s a modest house, the bottom rung of middle class. In the kitchen Sutter finds his mother, MARY (40s, faded beauty) already up and dressed in her work clothes. She moves in and out of the room as she readies for the long day, barely looking at her son.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You're up early.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I uh...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (not listening) They have me on a double shift... again. Sutter heads up to his room.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Dammit Sutter. Sutter stops in his tracks. Uh-oh. Mary comes out of the utility room holding her uniform jacket.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Didn’t I asked you to hang this for me? Look how wrinkled this is? That’s what she’s mad about?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It would have taken you two seconds to hang this up and help me. Is that too much to ask?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I just --

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It's not like I ask you to do so much around here. Christ. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (shakes head; almost to herself) Sometimes you act just like your father. Sutter’s face suggests that’s alright with him. Like a tornado, Mary passes through one last time.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I may not be back in time for dinner. There’s leftovers in the fridge. Or if you want, call your sister --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (hates that idea) No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: K, well, I’ve got to go. Sutter starts to walk off.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Sutter. Sutter turns back around.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Next time I ask you do to something... Mary doesn’t finish. She just shakes her head. And with that she’s out the door.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (to no one) I love you too. INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - LATER Sutter lays in his bed, looking up at the baseball pennant. Thinking. Miles Davis plays softly in the background. His alarm goes off but of course he doesn’t need it. He hasn’t slept. INT RICKY’S CAR - MORNING Ricky drives Sutter to school. Sutter has his flask and is back to his completely relaxed self.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: ..-who knew dinner and a movie would cost more than 30 bucks?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Pretty much anyone who’s ever been on a date.  24.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Oh but the best part is... she didn’t care, dude! She paid for the popcorn and everything. She’s just... mmm.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You kiss her?

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Check.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Tongue action?

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Double check. The boys high five. Sutter looks at Ricky and smiles. Likes seeing him happy. Knows he had a hand in it.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Wanna go to the Barons game tonight?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hell yeah.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: It's father/son night. We’ll pretend to be brothers. Hearing this, a look comes over Sutter’s face.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Oh I, uh, actually... shit. I forgot. There’s a... I promised my mom I'd help her with something.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: You sure? Sutter nods. Ricky turns back to the road. Sutter looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: So, uh, where to for lunch today?

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: I thought you were eating with what’s her name.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Oh shit. That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: I gotta tell ya Sutter. Aimee Finecky? Strange choice for a rebound.  25.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: She’s not a rebound. (off his look) She’s not! (another look) I have no interest in dating Aimee Finecky.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Then what’s the point of lunch?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I think she’s nice, is all. Maybe too nice. Did I tell you bout her paper route? Listen to this. Her mom has her throwing newspapers at 5am, 6 days a week, schooldays and all. She keeps all the money, pays half the bills, and Aimee never says a word about it!

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: That sucks.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: It’s bullshit’s what it is.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: So where do you come in?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I can help her.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Oh, here we go. Sutter to the rescue.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: She just needs a little confidence is all. Who better than me to bring it out of her?

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. So... you don’t want to nail her?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Dude, what is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: INT CLASSROOM
dialogues.text: MR. ASTER (50s, beard) solves a geometry problem on the chalkboard. The bell rings and students begin to leave.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ASTER
dialogues.text: Sutter, can I have a word?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Uh... actually I have to--  26.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ASTER
dialogues.text: Have a seat, Mr. Keely. Sutter really doesn’t want to have a seat but there’s not much he can do about it.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ASTER
dialogues.text: Noticed you didn’t turn in the homework.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (suddenly animated) And I have a really good reason why, Mr. Aster. You’re not even gonna believe it when I --

dialogues.speaker: MR. ASTER
dialogues.text: Stop talking.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ASTER
dialogues.text: Sutter, as your teacher, I only want to see you succeed. You know that, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Sure I do.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ASTER
dialogues.text: And if you fail... that means I fail.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I know, Mr. Aster. And believe me, I will get it together. From here on in.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ASTER
dialogues.text: I wanna believe you.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (standing) Well you should. I’m turning a corner, I promise --

dialogues.speaker: MR. ASTER
dialogues.text: Let’s see you answer this.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: MR. ASTER
dialogues.text: (handing him a sheet) If one of the acute angles is 2 times as large as the other, what’s the measure of the two angles? (no idea) Siddown, I’1ll show you.  27. Sutter is a deer in headlights.

dialogues.speaker: INT HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Sutter emerges from Aster’s class, super late to meet Aimee. He races through the hallway on his way to:

dialogues.speaker: INT LUNCHROOM
dialogues.text: Sutter enters, looking all around for her. Just as he thinks he’s missed her, there she is. Standing alone by the lunch line. Waiting.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry --

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You came!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Well of course I did. Why wouldn’t I? Sutter takes in the scene (only the lamest of the lame eat in the lunchroom).

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You actually eat here?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Isn’t that what it’s for?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Well yeah but nobody ever... I mean, I’ve never... (not wanting to insult) What’s good, I’m starving? He gets up to go to the lunch line, gesturing for her to come with.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: The tater tots are pretty solid. - LATER. Sutter and Aimee at the table.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: That’s so crazy! How fast were you going?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: 20, 25 miles per hour.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: And you just jumped out of the car? Aimee is hanging on every word.  28.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: There was snow on the ground. I didn’t think it would hurt.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: That’s amazing.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Look at you, you’re such a great listener. Ok, now you go.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Um... well, I remember... sophomore year. When you wore that mascot head to gym class and wouldn’t take it off...

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Oh yeah.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: That was so funny.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Yeah, no, I mean, stories about you.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I don’t have any stories.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Of course you do. Everyone does.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Not me.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Come on. What’s your thing?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: My thing?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Yeah, like... what do you love? What do you want to be known for? Larry Rourke’s the stoner. Greg Jacoby’s the rich kid. We all have a thing.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: (beat; thinks) I'd like to think there’s more to people than just one thing. You know? Sutter smiles, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Is that ok? At which point, a supremely uncool girl approaches. This is KRYSTAL.  29.

dialogues.speaker: KRYSTAL
dialogues.text: So he finally got here, did he?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Hi Krystal.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (standing like a gentleman) Krystal, hey, Sutter Keely.

dialogues.speaker: KRYSTAL
dialogues.text: I know who you are. Come on Aimee. French Club. They’re waiting for us. Aimee clearly wants to stay but standing up to people isn’t her thing.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I forgot about the meeting. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: No worries. As she’s walking away:

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hey Aimee, you ever have Aster for geometry?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Freshmen year.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Probably thought it was easy, huh?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Kind of.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Could you tutor me? I never know what that guy’s talking about.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Uh, sure, anytime. Aimee writes down her number and hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Terrific, thanks. I’1ll call you. Aimee nods, gets up to go, unable to hold back a smile. Krystal gives Sutter one last angry look before walking away. Sutter watches them go. Eats another tater tot. INT LEWIS FINE MEN’S CLOTHING STORE - DAY The store has seen better days. Sutter finishes up a sale to a customer.  30.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You're very welcome. It’s gonna look great on you. Customer leaves passing the owner, BOB LEWIS (late 30s, kind face) saying goodbye to his WIFE and BABY at the door. Sutter watches them go. Once they’re gone:

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Will you please just adopt me already?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Sorry bud, two’s my limit on mouths to feed. So where were we...

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Cassidy.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Oh right. That’s a shame. I really liked that one. When Bob is turned around, Sutter pours some whiskey into his soda can. Careful not to let Bob see this.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: So did I.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I kinda thought she’d be the one to yank you out of neutral.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Neutral? What neutral? I’m in overdrive. (off his look) What? EXT/INT AIMEE’S HOUSE - AFTERNOON A small brick cube surrounded by a bare yard. Some shingles are missing from the roof and the original paint color has faded away. Sutter knocks.

dialogues.speaker: CHILD'S VOICE FROM INSIDE
dialogues.text: Aimee, your boyfriend’s here. AIMEE’S VOICE (V.O.) Shut up Shane. Please. The door opens. Aimee has put some effort into her looks this afternoon. Most notably, she’s wearing lipstick. He'd never say so but Sutter would rather she wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hey there.  31.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Come in. Sutter follows Aimee inside. We take in the total mess that is Aimee’s living situation. Clothes piled up on the recliner, opened containers covering the tiny coffee table, VHS tapes scattered on the floor. Aimee’s little brother SHANE (11) plays an ancient video game system wearing shorts and no shirt.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: This is Shane, my brother.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hello Shane. Shane flips Sutter the two-handed bird.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: He just learned that.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Charming.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: We can study in my room.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Lead the way. Sutter follows Aimee down the narrow hallway. Notices more mess, some tacky wall hangings. Sutter catches a glimpse of Aimee’s step-dad RANDY, taking a nap in one room (dressed exactly like Shane). Finally they get to Aimee’s bedroom. Sutter is expecting the worst but when she opens the door, it’s an awesomely neat and colorful place, clearly a sanctuary from the world outside. Sutter is impressed.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Wow, nice.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I like to keep it clean. Sutter walks around the room, admiring. The back wall is a giant map of the Milky Way. There’s some pencil drawings and ceramic cats scattered about. On one wall is a massive bookshelf covered in notebooks and paperbacks. Welcome to Aimee’s World.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You must really love reading.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: They're mostly science fiction. A few mysteries.  32. Sutter picks up one book that’s half in Japanese. “Battle of the Immortal.”

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: (apologetically) I know it’s weird.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: No that’s cool. Weird is good. I say “embrace the weird.” Why’s it backwards?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: That’s how you read them. See? She shows Sutter how it works. He’s impressed. Notices on the wall one of the pencil drawings -- an anime-style scene of a woman flying through space.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Is this you flying through space?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: No, it’s, um... it’s nothing. Just this thing I like.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Who is she? Aimee is embarrassed... but Sutter silently encourages her to answer.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: She’s... Shirei Migoto. From the Bright Planet books. Stupid, I know.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: If you like it, it’s not stupid. What makes her so special?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: She’s the leader of the Neexo Ark. It’s up to her to escape the Dark Galaxy and find the Bright Planet star system.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (looking at another drawing) I... see... There’s drawings of the Commander everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: (still shyly) She’s kind of my hero... and stuff. Sutter feels exceedingly bad for this girl right now.  33.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You know what? You’ll be my hero if you can straighten me out on this geometry business.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Sure. They sit down and get situated. Sutter opens the big textbook.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: So... quadrilaterals. Talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: How much of this have you read? Sutter looks up. Smiles. He hasn’t read a word of course. - LATER. They’ve been at it a while.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: So, in this figure, angle 2 and angle 4 are... (Sutter has no clue) Complementary angles.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Complementary. Got it. Man, you’re a wonderful teacher, Miss Finecky.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: So then, you understand?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Well... here’s what I don’t understand. When on earth will I ever need to know this stuff?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Um...

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I mean, seriously. Vectors? Slopes? Coplanar lines? Who gives a shit? Who calculates slopes at their job? Aimee laughs. And then:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Aimee! Come out here right now, will you! The craggy voice belongs to Randy. Hearing it saps the fun vibe of the room almost immediately.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: My step-dad.  34.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: That’s ok.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We're all out of milk, Aimee. I thought you were going to get some.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I will!

dialogues.speaker: RANDY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Do it now, crissakes. The hell has she been doing all afternoon? It’s quiet for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I should really... Aimee smiles her sad smile, starts putting on her shoes.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. No problem. The expression on her face is like her ship just crashed back to Earth. Sutter feels terrible.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You know what, there’s this party on Saturday. I think you should go with me.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Yeah you. I’1ll come by and grab you around 8:30. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Um... ok?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Is that an answer or a question?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: No, I mean, yeah, yes. I'd like that.

dialogues.speaker: EXT STRIP MALL
dialogues.text: Sutter comes out of the convenience store with his Big Gulp. On the way to his car, he passes a comic book store. Sutter walks right by before stopping and turning around. INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Sutter finishes mixing a drink, turns on Thelonious Monk’s “Straight, No Chaser”, and sits down at his desk.  35. We see a stack of Manga books which Sutter bought at the store. He puts his feet up and begins to read through one in reverse. INSERT: elegantly drawn images from the books, the occasional caption about dreams, freedom, the future. Sutter finds himself surprisingly captivated. We hear the chime of an Instant Message. Sutter looks up from the book to his computer. He’s got a message from “CASSIDY210." (Her icon is a seductive personal pic). The message just says “Hey.” Sutter perks up. This is a nice, new development. He writes back... Sutter&7: “Hey.” (His icon: Sinatra). Takes a swig. Her message: “How are you?” Sutter drinks some more. Writes back: “Fabuloso.” Then it’s quiet for a few beats. Sutter scratches his head, thinking of the right thing to say. But then he gets this: “I_miss you.” Sutter’s eyes open wide. Writes back: “Will I see you tomorrow?” And then “Rlisa’s party.” Her message: “Think so.” Then, as Sutter is writing back, she sends: “Gotta _go. Talk soon.” And signs off. Sutter returns his attention to the Manga but his mind is now very much elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: EXT LAKE SIDE HIGH SCHOOL PARTY
dialogues.text: A bonfire. Picnic tables. Kegs. Music. Twenty or so high school kids already in the swing of things. Sutter and Aimee approach the party. Aimee wears an oversized purple winter coat that makes her look rotund. Sutter badly wants her to take it off.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You sure you don’t want me to carry your coat?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: It’s kinda chilly out. Oh well, he tried. As they walk towards the keg, pretty much everyone they pass says “Hi” to Sutter or slaps him five. He’s the king of these high school parties.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: See anyone you know?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I don’t really know a lot of people.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Well that, my dear, is about to change.  36. At the keg, Sutter is saluted by some classmates.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: How bout a brew?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Um, I don’t... really...

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Don’t drink it, just hold it. Gives off the illusion you’re having fun.

dialogues.speaker: JASON DOYLE
dialogues.text: Now it’s a party! This is JASON DOYLE (collar up, smarmy as hell). Sutter has no love for this dude.

dialogues.speaker: JASON DOYLE
dialogues.text: Whattup Sutterman? You gonna dive in the lake again tonight?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: JASON DOYLE
dialogues.text: You're crazy dude. (eyeing Aimee) And who might I ask is this?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Aimee. Jason and Aimee shake hands. Jason is either going to hit on her or poke fun at her. Sutter doesn’t care to find out which.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Doyle, what are you doing talking to us? Shouldn’t you be going for Alisa Norman now that she’s single?

dialogues.speaker: JASON DOYLE
dialogues.text: Alisa Norman? Since when?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Couple days.

dialogues.speaker: JASON DOYLE
dialogues.text: You shitting me?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I am shitting you not. Jason, intrigued, hurries off to find Alisa.  37.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (to Aimee) I am shitting him big time.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: (realizes) You're gonna get that guy killed!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Yeah I feel real bad about it. Aimee laughs. Takes a sip of her drink. Winces. But she takes another sip nonetheless.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You get used to it. Meanwhile, Sutter’s eyes land on a small, preppy kid with a baseball cap. He stands by a picnic table alone with his hands in his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Come with me. Sutter walks Aimee over to the kid, CODY DENNIS.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Cody, my man.

dialogues.speaker: CODY
dialogues.text: Hey Sutter.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You guys know each other? This is Aimee. They exchange sheepish “hellos.”

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Cody's a sophomore but he’s in all my classes. Aimee here’s a genius too. That doesn’t get them talking very much either. Hmm...

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You're a reader, aren’t you Cody? You ever read the Bright Planet books?

dialogues.speaker: CODY
dialogues.text: (cautiously) One or two.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (to Aimee) I forgot to tell you. I started the first one last night.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You did?  38.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: It's really cool. I like the part where Shirei Migoto takes on the Galactic Warlord. She fucks that guy up!

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I know, right?!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: And all that stuff about “inner prosperity.” Happiness from within. That’s my shit.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You should read the second one. It’s so awesome.

dialogues.speaker: CODY
dialogues.text: I love those books.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (of course he does) Do you? As Cody tries to get back into the convo, Sutter sees Cassidy appear. Her beauty makes him wince. Meanwhile:

dialogues.speaker: CODY
dialogues.text: Have you read “Solar Bull?”

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Oh my god, I love Solar Bull!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Haven't read that one yet. Cody and Aimee start enthusiastically chatting about it.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You know what. You guys discuss. I’ll be back in like, two seconds. Ok? Aimee and Cody don’t mind. Sutter starts to walk towards Cassidy. On the way, however, he turns back to make sure Aimee is ok. Seeing she’s fine, Sutter makes his way over to Cassidy. She waves. He waves back -- only to discover it wasn’t him she was waving to. It was Marcus. They hug tightly. This stings. Sutter quickly ducks in the direction of the keg. TWO CLASSMATES are playing Beirut.

dialogues.speaker: CLASSMATE
dialogues.text: ... I was so pumped when I got in.

dialogues.speaker: CLASSMATE
dialogues.text: Yeah no shit.  39.

dialogues.speaker: CLASSMATE
dialogues.text: I can’t wait to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: CLASSMATE
dialogues.text: Fucking five more months. (sees Sutter) Hey Sutter.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What’s up guys? Sutter refills his cup, keeping one eye on Cass and Marcus.

dialogues.speaker: CLASSMATE
dialogues.text: Mike’s here if you wanna surf on his car again.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Maybe later. Sutter downs one drink, pours two more, carries them over to Cassidy.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hello gang.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Sutter.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (to Cass) Who could use a drink?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: (as expected) Sure. Sutter notices that the crew around Cass and Marcus seem to be waiting for some kind of incident. Well he’s not going to give them one.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Everyone’s so serious tonight. (beat) How bout a joke? What do you call a fish with no eye? They all wait for it.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: A fsshh. It takes a second but eventually Cass starts to laugh. The others join in.  40.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Heard that from an 8 year old running away from home. Want another? Where would you find a dog with no legs...? Right where you left him. Even Marcus finds this one funny. Denver, the athlete, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: DENVER
dialogues.text: What are you guys laughing at?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Sutter.

dialogues.speaker: DENVER
dialogues.text: I should have guessed.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I know. I’m hilarious.

dialogues.speaker: DENVER
dialogues.text: Anyone see Alisa?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Did you two break up or something?

dialogues.speaker: DENVER
dialogues.text: No. Why’d you say that?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Sorry. I thought I saw her with Jason Doyle.

dialogues.speaker: DENVER
dialogues.text: What the fuck --! Denver turns to go find Jason and kick his ass.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Denver, slow down! But he’s off. Jason Doyle is in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: (to Cass) I'll be right back. The other guys go with them, leaving Cass and Sutter alone. Sutter has a canary eating smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (winks) Me? Nothing.  41. LATER. Sutter and Cassidy are catching up by the keg.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: So Ricky and Beth are officially together?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I wonder how that happened.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: You really weren’t going for Tara that night?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Are you nuts? (holds hands out like scales) Over here I have cute little Tara. Nice girl. Good skin. Attractive. But over here, I have spanktaculiciously perfect you. Who do you think I would choose? Cassidy blushes, causing Sutter to smile.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Don’t give me that smile.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I can’t help myself. At which point a shout rises up on the other side of the crowd. Catcalls of “Fight! Fight!” are audible.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Guess they found Doyle. Sutter and Cass move to get a closer look. Denver is on top of someone, pushing him into the ground. Marcus is trying to hold him back. Cass runs to Marcus’s aid, leaving Sutter alone. But when Sutter is able to see the kid being beaten, it isn’t Jason at all. That’s weird. Confused, he looks around for Jason and finally sees him away from the crowd, standing against a tree -- talking with Aimee.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Fuck. Sutter makes haste over to Aimee, noticing that she looks ready to hurl at any moment.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What’s going on here? Where’s Cody?

dialogues.speaker: JASON DOYLE
dialogues.text: Couldn’t handle the competition.  42.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (to Aimee) You all right?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Um, yeah, I’m just, you know, not used to drinking.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Let’s go for a walk. Sutter grabs Aimee and helps her up.

dialogues.speaker: JASON DOYLE
dialogues.text: Hey, man, what the --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Get lost douchebag. Sutter takes Aimee by the arm and walks her in another direction. As he does, he catches Cassidy watching him with Aimee. LATER. They walk on a dirt road, far away from the rest of the revelers.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You sure you’re alright?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Thank you. I’m a little... you know.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You like it?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: It’s good. It’s... different.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hey, I’m sorry about Doyle. He’s a dick. I hope he didn’t --

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: No, we were just... we were just talking.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Wow. You're hammered, aren’t you? Aimee leans up against Sutter. Their shoulders touching. She looks at him and smiles. Sutter isn’t sure what to do so he takes a nip from the flask.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Can I try that?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: This? No. This is some serious stuff.  43.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Just a taste. Sutter hesitates but then hands it to her. She takes more than a sip and is immediately coughing and choking. He smiles

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: How can you drink this?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I’ve been at it a while. You know who gave me my first beer?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: My father. I was probably... 6. We used to go to baseball games every Saturday and he would let me take little sips.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Did you get drunk?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Nah. But it sure felt nice and warm... at this memory.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Where is he now... your father?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: He’s an airline pilot. Flies all over the country.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: That’s so cool!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: He’s a cool guy. The best. I don’t know what he was doing with my mom that whole time.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: They’re divorced?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. She threw him out of the house a long time ago. (beat) But it’s fine. Believe me, he’s way better off now. Aimee takes another sip. Winces but doesn’t choke.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Sounds like we have the same mother.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: How’s that?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Well for example... I got into college today and there’s no way my mom will let me go.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (beat) You got into college today?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: No shit!

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: In St. Louis. Where my sister lives.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: That's, I don’t know what to say, Aim. Congratulations!

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter, though... cause my mom

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hold on. What’s your mom have to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: She needs me. There’s no one else to help with the route.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (disbelief) Aimee, seriously. Your mom will be fine. She’s a grown woman. You have to go to St. Louis.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Yeah but --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: No. No buts. Don’t you see? You’re like this extraordinary genius chick but you've got all these people making you do stuff. It’s gotta stop.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: It’s your life! Stand up for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s not that easy.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I'll teach you. Here... have another swig. Aimee takes the flask. Drinks another sip.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Now repeat after me. “Mom, get off my motherfucking back!”

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Say it.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: No! (beat; quietly) Get off my back.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Dude, you've got to say it like you mean it. And the motherfuck is key. Trust me. “Mom...”

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: “Get off my MOTHERFUCKING back, Mom!”

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: (beat) “Get off my... fucking... back, Mom!”

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Motherfucking.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Motherfucking back! Motherfucker! Aaaah!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: That sorta feels good.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I told you.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Get off my motherfucking back, mom. Stay out of my motherfucking business, Krystal. 45.  46.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Oh! Krystal got one. Who else?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I think that’s it.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: How bout an ex-boyfriend? Fuck you ex- boyfriend! Aimee clamps up. Sutter notices.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Come on. You can’t be 17 and not have one horrible ex-boyfriend you want to curse out. (she doesn’t) Nobody?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: It’s not... guys don’t really look at me... like that. You know?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You're crazy. Didn’t you see Jason Doyle hitting on you? And Cody Dennis?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: They weren’t hitting on me.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Of course they were. You’re a sweetheart. I mean, look at you. Aimee is not at all convinced. To convince her, Sutter takes hold of her chin, tilts it up, and plants a kiss on her. When it’s over:

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Whew.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You’re damn right “whew.” Sutter smiles. Aimee smiles back. So Sutter goes in for another one. Why the hell not? And as they kiss, CUT TO: INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - THE NEXT DAY Sutter’s asleep in his clothes from the night before. Food wrappers and a stray beer can are littered around the bed. The clock reads: 12:06pm. Sutter stirs. Moans. The hangover is upon him.  47.

dialogues.speaker: INT BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Sutter showers. He leans against the wall, head in his arms as the water falls on him. He tries to remember the night before. - FLASH: Sutter and Aimee walk away from the party. Cassidy watching. BACK TO Sutter in the shower. Remembering. - FLASH: Sutter kissing Aimee, like we saw. BACK TO Sutter in the shower. Ok, yeah, that happened. - FLASH: Sutter helping Aimee to get to her front door.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Of course you’re going to the prom. I’1l take you. BACK TO Sutter in the shower. Can’t believe he said that. Rolls back his head in disgust. INT RICKY’S HOUSE - LATER Sutter and Ricky watch a baseball game on TV. Sutter fixes himself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: You made plans with her? Like, future plans?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: It’s no big deal.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: It’s you making plans. You never make plans.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Relax, will you? I’m just trying to help the girl.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Right I forgot. Sutter to the rescue.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: And if she falls for you, what happens then? Sutter dismisses this as nonsense. Ricky holds his gaze.  48. INT SUTTER’S HOUSE - LATER Sutter comes in. Walks into the kitchen. Puts down his stuff. There’s a message on the answering machine. He presses play and hears: AIMEE’S VOICE Sutter, hi, it’s, um, it’s Aimee. Wasn’t sure if we were studying tonight. Call me. If you want. Sutter barely reacts to the message. As he listens, he goes to the fridge. Reads a note from Mom, something about working late and chicken in the microwave. Sutter doesn’t react to that either. Whistling, he bypasses the food and goes straight to the liquor cabinet. INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - LATER Sutter sits in front of his computer, stirring a drink. He looks at the application essay he has written ("Describe a hardship...”) Sutter highlights the essay (from our opening) and deletes the whole thing. He takes a deep breath. Is about to start over when he hears a sound. ON SCREEN we see “CASSIDY210 is now online”. Sutter opens the chat window. We see “Sutter&7” send her a message: “Hey, beautiful.” Sutter waits for a response. Gets one: Hello you...” Sutter thinks about what to say next. Writes: “What are you doing? Let’s hang out.” Sutter debates sending that. One beat. Two beats. Wills himself to hit send.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response. Now he’s nervous. Then it comes: “I’m heading out to the mall.” Sutter sits back in his chair. About to give up. And then he receives: “Wanna come?”

dialogues.speaker: INT MALL
dialogues.text: They pass Sutter’s flask back and forth as they walk, reminiscing.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: .«.-and the time under the bleachers. Who could ever forget that?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Remember the lightning storm?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: On your roof! That was amazing!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You’re telling me.  49.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: (beat; reflective) I don’t know how many times I’ve ever felt like that.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Not a lot.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: But every time was with you.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I think I feel it right now. Cassidy smiles and walks on.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Stop it.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: It’s true. When we’re together, it’s like, we’re invincible. Like nothing can touch us, like everything else in the world - the problems, the responsibilities - they all just disappear. Sutter looks right in her eyes. Cassidy looks down.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to lose you Sutter. Sutter tenderly touches her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Then you won't. She looks back up at him. Deciding. INT CASSIDY’S BEDROOM - LATER And now they’re making out on Cassidy’s bed. Clothes are coming off. Every time Sutter tries to say something, she bites his lip.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: God you're beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Don’t talk. Cassidy lies down. They continue kissing. Sutter moves to her neck. Suddenly her hands stop moving and her body freezes. Sutter is confused.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Just go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What do you mean, ‘just go ahead’?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Just do it. She lies perfectly still with her eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I can’t... I’m not gonna just do it. What’s wrong with you? Sutter pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Are you thinking about Marcus? (she says nothing) Are you in love with him?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to talk about him right now.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: It’s just a yes or no thing. I’m not asking for a whole essay.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: I don’t know... Maybe. (starts to cry) I'm, like, really confused right now.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What about us? This afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: That's what got me so confused. Today has been... great.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: But?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: We always have fun. I mean, I don’t have fun with anyone like I do with you.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I agree --

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: But you can’t go around having fun all the time. Sometimes you have to be serious.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I am serious. I’m 100 percent serious. 50.  51.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: About... not being serious. Enjoying things. Living in the moment.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: I want more than just... “moments.” I want --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: A future. Sutter looks away. Starts to get dressed.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Are you mad?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I’m not mad. Whatever. You and I... friends. That’s terrific. Music up: a girl singing a contemporary folk song on acoustic guitar. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: INT MOTEL ROOM
dialogues.text: On Sutter’s utterly distraught face, we PULL BACK TO REVEAL he is at a birthday party, where all the kids are drinking pop and watching a pig-tailed GIRL play a song about Jesus on the guitar. He looks at Ricky who sits on the couch holding hands with Beth. They actually seem to be enjoying this. Sutter can’t take it anymore. Gets up and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: INT MOTEL
dialogues.text: Sutter walks down the stairs, wanders through the atrium.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yo, Carmine! Sutter turns. It’s SHAWNIE BROWN (18, brunette, funky glasses, hip), on her way inside.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Ay Carmine, how you doin’?

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: I’m doin’ bravissimo, Carmine. Whatchoo doin?  52.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Just tryin’ to put some distance between me and dem stiffs upstairs at dat lame- ass party.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: Ay-oh, I was just goin’ to that. No good?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Fuggettaboudit.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: No, you fuggettaboudit.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Aaaay, you're breakin’ my balls. They both burst out laughing and hug.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: So, really, the party’s lame?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Whatever you do Shawnie, do not go in there.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: Shit. There’s, like, nothing else going on tonight.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (holding up his flask) There’s always something going on when I’m around.

dialogues.speaker: INT MOTEL GAME ROOM
dialogues.text: A couple of old arcade games in the corner and a beat up ping pong table. They talk while playing ping pong.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you tell me that before I started dating him?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Would it have made a difference?

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: Probably not... Point game. (she serves) What about you?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What about me?

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: What’s up with you and Cassidy?  53.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Cassidy who?

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: (not buying it) Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: The past is past, Shawnie Brown. You know me. I live in the now. She smashes a shot past Sutter.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: Woo! Three games in a row, sucker.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Ping pong’s not my game.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: Clearly.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (eyes a hot tub in the next room) Now that’s what I need. Sutter races to it, Shawnie follows. He feels the water.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: You're not really going in there, are you?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Of course I am.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: Bullshit. Sutter steps into the hot tub, fully dressed. He eases himself down into the tub.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: You're crazy.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Yeah but that’s why you like me so much. So, Miss Queen of Ping Pong, your move...

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: You can never outdo me, Sutter. Shawnie follows him in, her white t-shirt clinging to her body, showing all. Sutter’s mouth drops and Shawnee smiles at him, knowing she’s won. For a beat they sit there together. And then, almost without thinking, Sutter kisses her.  54. It works -- for about a second before Shawnie starts giggling. Then it’s a full-blown laugh. Sutter can’t help but to laugh too. It’s contagious.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: You know what, Sutter? You’re my favorite ex-boyfriend of all time. I’m sure going to miss you next year.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Why, where you going?

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: College. (beat) Aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Haven’t really thought about it.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, right. (beat) Wait, you’re serious? Sutter shrugs. Shawnie splashes him in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: You’re not going to college?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: Sutter!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: It’s fucking college!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: My Dad never went to college and now he’s, like, the number two real estate developer in Cook County. Who needs it? I have everything I need right here. A job. A car... A naked girl in a hot tub. Shawnie laughs. Sutter smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Look at us. This moment right here. You're gonna remember this, aren’t you? It’s beautiful. You think beauty’s in some classroom? A text book? It’s not. It's here. It’s all around us.  55.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: You're drunk.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Yeah but I’m not wrong. Shawnie thinks about it. Not completely wrong anyway.

dialogues.speaker: SHAWNIE
dialogues.text: Ay, you're breakin’ my balls here.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You're breakin’ my balls! They engage in a friendly splash fight as we TRACK AWAY. CuT TO: INT SUTTER’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Sutter comes in and sits at his computer. Again opens the college application window. The essay is now totally blank. He looks at the question. Quick glance to the pennant on the wall. Sutter takes a swig from the flask. Says out loud:

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Fuck this. And turns off the computer.

dialogues.speaker: INT HIGH SCHOOL HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Crowded with kids heading in all directions. And then there’s Sutter. He strolls down the hall until he spots Aimee at a distance. Her back is turned. Sutter quickly turns down another hallway.

dialogues.speaker: EXT SCHOOL PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: Sutter is walking to his Lancer when:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Just who do you think you are? It's Krystal Krittenbrink, and she doesn’t look happy.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: The King of Mexico?

dialogues.speaker: KRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Don’t think you’re going to joke your way out of this, Sutter. Aimee told me about your little party out by the lake.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
