dialogues.text: And?  56.

dialogues.speaker: KRYSTAL
dialogues.text: And now you’re avoiding her.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I’m not avoiding anyone.

dialogues.speaker: KRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Really? Have you seen her since the party? Have you even called?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: How bout you get off my back?

dialogues.speaker: KRYSTAL
dialogues.text: Ha, I knew Aimee got that from you. She said the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Did she? Good for her.

dialogues.speaker: KRYSTAL
dialogues.text: No, it’s not good for her. Aimee’s isn’t like you, Sutter. She’s a sweet girl. She doesn’t need you causing problems in her life.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (walking away) The only problem Aimee has is you bossing her around like she’s your personal assistant.

dialogues.speaker: KRYSTAL
dialogues.text: (yelling after him) You shouldn’t treat her this way.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (not stopping) Whatever buzzkill. INT SUTTER’S CAR - LATER Sutter drives around. Takes a drink from the Big Gulp. We can tell he’s thinking about what Krystal said. Rolls his eyes and makes a U-Turn. EXT AIMEE’S HOUSE - DUSK Sutter knocks. It takes a few moments for the door to open. It’s Shane. Before Sutter can say anything Shane turns his head.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: Aimee! Your boyfriend’s back!

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What? Oh, um, tell him to hold on a second, I’ll be right there.  57.

dialogues.speaker: SHANE
dialogues.text: (cunning off) You tell him!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (to no one) Bye Shane. Sutter waits in the doorway. Drinks. After a few moments Aimee appears. She’s wearing what looks like a new shirt and her hair is all staticky from a quick brushing.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I didn’t know you were coming over today.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Yeah, no, I wasn’t, but uh... I was driving around and I thought, ‘I don’t care how busy I am. I want to see how Aimee’s doing.’ (off her smile) So... how you doing?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Good. Great. Listen, my sister is having a dinner for her swanky friends and I’m being forced to show --

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You have a sister? I didn’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, we’re not really close. Anyway, would you wanna come with me?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Um... ok! When is it?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Oh. Uh... Sure! I’ll go get my coat.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Let’s leave the coat. INT HOLLY’S DINING ROOM - LATER ANGLE on HOLLY, Sutter’s sister, (25, heavily made up, dyed blonde hair, fake breasts and dressed to show them, jewelry glistening everywhere).  58.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: »--and I said “could I get you boys anything else?” And he said, tell ‘em what you said honey. Holly’s husband JOE (early 40s, confident without cause) sits to her right.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I leaned back in my chair, puffed out my chest and I said... “You could give me your number gorgeous?” The PARTY GUESTS (mostly OLDER MEN and their YOUNGER SECOND WIVES) like this. Sutter, at the other end of the long table, makes the “vomit” face to Aimee. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: I had no idea he was a big fancy lawyer but I gave it to him anyway. And I’m sure glad I did!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Hasn't worked a day in her life since. Joe squeezes her leg. Holly pecks her husband on the lips. Aimee rolls her eyes at this. Signals for another top-off from the flask which Sutter provides out of view from the others.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Isn't that a great story?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Wow. You guys sure are a breath of fresh air.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Thank you Sutter.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: It’s rare to see such happy couples nowadays. Seems like everyone’s divorced.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: That’s not true.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Isn't it? My parents, (to Aimee) your parents, most of my friend’s parents --

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Kid’s got a point.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Thank you Joe.  59.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Mine didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (confused) They didn’t? But I thought... Aimee shakes her head no.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: See Sutter. Not everything is doomed.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: My Dad died. That sucks the air out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Not your fault. Aimee takes a drink. The guests shuffle in their seats.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Oh honey, what happened?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: He was a great guy. He just... he had a... problem. Painkillers, mostly. No one really knows what to say.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: He tried to stop a bunch of times, but... One day my sister came home and he was just lying there. She had to close his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Jesus. She takes another sip of her drink but this time doesn’t flinch.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: (to Sutter) Anyway, I don’t agree with you. About marriage. Mine’s gonna totally work.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I’ve thought it all out. We’re going to live on a horse ranch, my husband and I. I’ll work for NASA. And my husband... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sutter is 60.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: he'll do something completely different. And we'll offset each other. Like we’ll have some things in common but we’ll also have all these other dimensions that we bring to the relationship. And that’s how I know it’ll work. taken aback. Really impressed with her now.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (dismissive) Sounds like a dream.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: (cight back at him) It’s good to have dreams. Don’t you think? Aimee looks at Sutter, smiles. Sutter, still stunned, smiles back. Raises his glass.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: To dreams.

dialogues.speaker: EXT WATER TOWER
dialogues.text: Where kids hang out cause there’s nowhere to go. Away from the party, Sutter and Aimee share a drink sitting on the roof of his car.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Did you mean what you said at the party?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Uh... which... thing --?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: When you asked me to the Prom?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (beat) Well of course I remember that. Are you kidding? I wouldn’t forget something like that. There’s an awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Do you still want to go? I mean, if you don’t, I'll understand.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? I totally want to go. I wouldn’t have asked you if I didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Really?  61.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Sure. Can’t wait. She looks at him and smiles. He smiles back. Starting to really like how happy he makes this girl.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (shutting off radio) Come here. They start to kiss. Sutter then stops. Takes off her glasses. Sets them on the hood. Kissing resumes. This lasts a few seconds before someone whistles at them from the water tower. Aimee and Sutter laugh.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Come on. I’ll take you home.

dialogues.speaker: INT HIGH SCHOOL HALLWAY
dialogues.text: In the hallway, Aimee kisses Sutter goodbye. Holds on to his arm for as long as she can as they part. Sutter goes one way, she goes the other. Ricky joins Sutter with a disapproving look.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: It’s under control. (Ricky shakes his head) Hey, did it ever cross your mind that I might actually be attracted to her?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: That’s cause you haven’t really looked at her. I’m telling you. You have to talk to her a while before you can really see her. Ricky’s expression doesn’t change.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What am I doing that’s so wrong? Really? Worst case scenario, I’m giving her some much needed boyfriend experience.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: That's worst case scenario?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Totally. (Ricky still shakes his head) You and I both know, another month tops before she’s done with me and moves on.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: And what if she doesn’t?  62.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Well then that would be a first, wouldn’t it? Fair point. Jason Doyle walks over.

dialogues.speaker: JASON DOYLE
dialogues.text: Hey Sutter, Marcus was looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Marcus? What for?

dialogues.speaker: JASON DOYLE
dialogues.text: I‘ll let him tell you that. Jason walks away, smiling maliciously. Sutter and Ricky look at one another, knowing that can’t be good. INT LEWIS'S FINE MEN’S CLOTHING STORE - DAY Sutter is shadowboxing while talking to Bob at the men’s shop.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: »--and he’s like yay big and I’m like yay big... so that’s bad. Plus, he’s fast. And his reach has got to be way out --

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Sutter, what are you doing? You’re not a fighter.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Tell me about it!

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: So why’s he want to fight you?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I don’t know. He must think I’m still after Cassidy.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Is he right? Sutter stops boxing (clearly winded). Takes a drink from his Big Gulp.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: No. I mean -- we talk, a little. Online mostly. (off his look) Hey, I’m the victim here. She chose him. (beat) Just cause I want to keep in touch with my ex doesn’t make me a bad guy. Does it?  63.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You're not a bad guy, Sutter. You just don’t have a real good grasp of the idea of consequences. LATER. Sutter turns off the lights. Goes outside, locking the door behind him. Big Gulp in hand. As he walks to his car:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: We need to talk. Oh shit, it’s Marcus. Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Ok sure. Long as it’s quick --

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: What’s up with you and Cassidy?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Nothing’s up. Why, what have you heard? Marcus just stares Sutter down. Intimidating.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Look, man, I don’t want any trouble.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Tell me the truth. Marcus gets right up in Sutter’s face. Sutter knows if this gets physical, he’s not gonna win.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: We're just friends. Honestly. She’s moved on. I’ve moved on...

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: You've moved on?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (not convincingly) I have.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Everyone knows you’d drop Aimee Finecky in a second if Cass would go back to you.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Everyone knows that? Well guess what... everyone’s wrong. (beat) Look, Marcus, trust me, ok. We hang out sometimes, we have fun, but I promise you, nothing’s going on between Cass and me.  64. Marcus continues to stare Sutter down. A beat. And then it’s Marcus who breaks the stare first. He looks down at his feet. Sutter realizes something -- he isn’t angry, he’s distressed.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: (beat) Can I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Oh...k.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Why can’t it be me she has fun with?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (beat; not expecting that) What?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: I’m not like you, Sutter. I don’t know how to make her laugh and stuff. I want to, I just... I don’t know what to do. Can you help me? The direction of this conversation has thrown Sutter for a loop. Sutter is

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Dude... you’re Marcus West. Star athlete. Class President. What’s that charity you started?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: The Hope Brigade.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: The Hope Brigade, for fuck’s sake. You're the man, Marcus! You don’t need my help.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: The way she talks about you... it’s not the same, man. I want her to like me like that. And she doesn’t. I know she doesn’t. stunned to see Marcus so distraught and vulnerable. This is too weird.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Look, Marcus, you don’t want to be like me. Trust me. I make jokes and stuff but you... you get shit done. You’re gonna change the world. You guys are perfect together. Marcus’s mood is slowly improving. Sutter is on a roll.  65.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You just need to loosen up a bit. You're too tense.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: All that charity work you do. Volunteering. It’s nice but, I mean come on, you’re young. Not everything has to be serious all the time. See a movie. Maybe have a beer once in a while.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: That’s not for me, man.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I'm just saying... relax. Enjoy yourself, you know? Live in the now. Marcus sighs, taking it all in. What Sutter’s saying makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Thank you for talking to me like this, Sutter. I appreciate it. I really do.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Well sure --

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: You’re a good man. Sutter nods, feeling pretty good about the whole thing. Marcus walks back to his car.

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: Hey Sutter! (Sutter turns) They’re wrong about you.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: You're not the joke everyone thinks. Sutter flinches, as if he just received the punch he was expecting all along. Marcus leaves and we remain on Sutter, thinking about that. CUT TO: INT AIMEE’S LIVING ROOM - LATER Sutter and Aimee sitting close together on her couch, watching TV.  66.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What do you think of the movie?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I’ve seen it before.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Oh. We can watch something else.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: No I like it. Used to watch it with my Dad all the time. He loved this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Really? My kind of guy.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You would have liked him a lot. He’s the one who turned me onto music and manga and stuff. He was cool. Sutter puts his arms around her. Aimee likes the feeling.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: What about you?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Do you miss your Dad?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Nah it’s cool.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: He’s not flying back soon?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You said he was an... airline pilot.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Um... yeah, exactly.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: So... why can’t he fly to come see you?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Why are we talking about this?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: It's important. If my Dad was alive --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I'm trying to watch the movie.  67.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I’m just saying... you should see him, before it’s too late. Sutter says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Maybe you can ask your mom --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (jumping up) Goddamit Aimee! Will you shut up already? Jesus Christ. Aimee’s face flushes red and she shrinks away. This is the first time Sutter’s gotten mad at her and it stings.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (cvealizing he snapped) No, I’m sorry. You just... kept going on and on.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: (looking away) I know. I don’t know what’s wrong with me.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (sitting back down) Nothing’s wrong with you. I’m just... a little touchy about my Dad, ok. Come here. I’m sorry I yelled. Sutter hugs her tight. He then lifts her chin to look at him. Then he kisses her. The mouth. The forehead. The eyelids. Kissing the tears away. It grows in intensity. INT AIMEE’S BEDROOM - MOMENTS LATER And now they’re on the bed, kissing, fondling.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Can we take off our clothes? There’s no stopping it now. Sutter lifts off Aimee’s shirt. Aimee takes off her own bra. Sutter then takes his shirt off. Aimee helps him with his pants. It’s awkward but there’s a real romance to it. Sutter sees Aimee in a new light. And he’s amazed at what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Nudity looks awesome on you.  68. They get under the covers together. Feeling each other's bodies. Aimee stops first. Reaching over to the night stand. She pulls out a condom.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Just to be safe. Sutter is surprised. Girl’s got all the bases covered. Aimee helps him put the condom on. And then pulls him over towards her so he can be on top.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I like you so much.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You're spectacular. You really are.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I’m so glad I met you.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I'm glad I met you too. Slowly, tenderly, they begin to have sex. Sutter looks down at Aimee’s face. Her eyes are closed. It’s very different from sex with Cassidy but in a way it’s better. More intimate. More connected. Sutter is entranced. - LATER. They lie in bed together. Post-coital.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You're incredible.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Nah. It’s easy to seem that way on your first time. (Aimee looks away) It was your first time, wasn’t it...? Aimee? Her silence says maybe it wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I thought you said you never had a boyfriend. Aimee sits up, pulls her knees to her chest. Chin down, looking very distraught.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to hate me.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hate you? I won’t hate you. You’re un- hatable.  69.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: It’s just something that happened... I was 14. I didn’t know anything about boys.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Ok.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Randy’s son Troy was sleeping over.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Randy? Your Step-father Randy?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: (nods) We all went to sleep and then I heard this knock on my door. Troy said he couldn’t sleep and would I mind if he came in, talked for a while.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Of course he did.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: He climbed in my bed. Got under the covers. And started... saying all this stuff to me...

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What kind of stuff?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You know. How warm I feel. How much he likes my mouth and my hair.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Smooth talker, this Troy.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: No one ever spoke to me like that. It felt... I don’t know... special. So I just... let him do it. (beat) I should have known better.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: How could you? You were 14.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I still should have known no 20 year old would actually like me --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: 20? Are you fucking kidding me?  70.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: And the worst part is... when we... finished... he couldn’t look at me. Drove away in the morning. I’ve never seen him since.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Oh man! That dude is king of the creeps. If I ever see that guy -- I can’t believe your mom stayed with Randy after that.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I never told her.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You never... How could you not --

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I’ve never told anyone that. Until now. They both lie there quietly. Aimee puts her head on his chest. Sutter sits there thinking. Then he hears her lose it.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Don’t cry.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You must think I’m awful.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I don’t think you’re awful. Why would you say that? (beat) I‘ll tell you a secret. (beat) My Dad’s not a pilot... I’m not sure what he is. Or where. I just said that because... I don’t know... I don’t know anything about him. He’s been gone half my life and I... I guess I just miss him.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Doesn’t anyone know where he is?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Just my mom. She refuses to tell me.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: That’s terrible! She can’t keep him from you. He’s your father. Sutter looks away. Uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: (beat) I’‘ll make you a deal. I’ll stand up to my Mom, if you stand up to yours.  71. Sutter looks at her. Aimee puts out her hand to shake.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: What do you say? Deal? Sutter hesitates. Then he just smiles, touches her face. Instead of answering he says:

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You're spectacular. And then they lay together. She strokes his hair as he looks at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: INT SCHOOL AUDITORIUM
dialogues.text: Sutter waits in line to take his Yearbook picture. Cassidy approaches.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: (fixes his hair) There you go.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Haven’t seen you in a while.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: How's Marcus?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Good. How’s Aimee?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Couldn’t be better. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: I gotta say, Sutter, I’m impressed. (off his look) I admire you... for going out with her.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: “Admire?” That’s an odd word.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: No I mean... you don’t usually go for those kinds of girls.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What can I say? I’m evolving.  72.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: (coy) . Maybe you’ll amount to something after all.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I'm already something. I’m a miraculous marvel is what I am. She laughs. It’s comfortable between them.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Anyway... I'd better get back. Good seeing you. She turns to go. He watches.

dialogues.speaker: INT HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Sutter is walking to class when he hears:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Sutter! Mr. Aster calls to him from inside his classroom.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ASTER
dialogues.text: Would you come in here please? Sutter exhales and turns left into Aster’s class.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ASTER
dialogues.text: Have a seat. Aster hands him a homework assignment. A big red D+.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (upbeat) It’s not an F.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ASTER
dialogues.text: I thought you were getting help.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ASTER
dialogues.text: Well now you need a C on the final or you fail my class.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I’ll try harder.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ASTER
dialogues.text: No you won't. That takes Sutter by surprise.  73.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ASTER
dialogues.text: I don’t get you, Sutter. You’re a smart kid. Thoughtful. Do you even want to graduate?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (beat; thinks about it) I’m not sure.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ASTER
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I'm being honest with you. The truth is, I really don’t know. I like it here. I like being young. Everybody’s rushing me to grow up, move on -- why? What’s so great about it? Aster doesn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Are you happy, Mr. Aster? Aster is silent. Sutter shrugs. Takes his paper and goes. INT AIMEE’S HOUSE - PROM NIGHT Tuxedo-clad Sutter stands in the kitchen with Aimee’s MOM and Randy. Aimee’s Mom has the camera out and is readying to take some prom pictures. AIMEE’S MOM Randy, get in there with Sutter. The two men pose for the picture. As odd a couple as you're likely to see. Sutter pretends to be comfortable. Finally Aimee comes down. She’s wearing the lipstick again, her dress is a pale yellow that doesn’t quite match her skin tone, and she’s done her hair up in a leaning tower of Pisa style do. An awkward girl trying too hard to look elegant. Sutter doesn’t care about that.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You look fabuloso.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Thanks. So do you. They do the boutonniere/ corsage exchange. Mom takes a few more. Randy’s already turned his attention to the game on TV. They say their goodbyes and they’re off. INT SUTTER’S CAR - LATER Sutter’s car has been washed for the occasion. They sit together.  74.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Sorry I didn’t get you a limo.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: That’s ok.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Let me make it up to you. He pulls out a small wrapped gift from the glove compartment.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You didn’t have to --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I wanted to. Aimee tears the wrapping paper off of the box. Opens it. A flask.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Just like mine. And you’ll notice it’s already full too.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I love it!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Shall we (toast)? (vaising his flask) To you, Aimee Finecky. They toast. Aimee leans in to kiss him. When it’s over:

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Ok then. Let’s go to prom!

dialogues.speaker: EXT HORSE RACING TRACK
dialogues.text: Sutter and Aimee arrive at the venue which, when not hosting a high school prom, is a horse track. Tonight it’s lit up with white Xmas lights and made to look very romantic. Aimee adjusts the straps on her ill-fitting dress. Sneaks a drink from her flask. Sutter takes Aimee’s arm and they walk inside.

dialogues.speaker: INT BANQUET HALL
dialogues.text: The prom is already in full swing and it’s very much like you'd expect -- DJ, punch bowl, padded chairs, white tablecloths. Through Sutter’s eyes, the whole place sparkles. People greet him as they always do when he shows up to a party. High-fives etc. Sutter and Aimee choose a half- empty table to sit at. Sutter pulls out a chair for her like a gentleman. They sit and take it all in.  75.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You want some punch?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Back in a jiff. Sutter heads over to the punch bowl. Pours two glasses. Nods to Ricky who is sitting with Beth. And then he sees Cassidy, on the dance floor with Marcus. Her dress is amazing, showing off her voluptuous body in the perfect way. Sutter takes a moment to watch but then shakes it off, heads back to his table, hands Aimee the punch which she immediately spikes.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Cheers. Sutter wants to give Aimee his full attention but his eyes can’t help returning to Cassidy. Eventually:

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: She’s a good dancer.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Cassidy.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, I hadn’t noticed. Aimee doesn’t push the issue. Sutter downs another drink. And so does Aimee. The song ends and Cassidy sees Sutter at the table. She walks over with Marcus.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Why aren’t you two dancing?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You know I hate this kind of music.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Who cares? It’s the prom. Aimee, c’mon!

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I’m not much of a dancer.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: That's why you got me. I can teach you some of my moves.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: (taking a big sip) I’m good right here. You two go ahead.  76. Sutter and Cassidy share a look.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: It’s fine. Aimee takes out her flask and re-spikes the drink. Sutter hesitates for a beat, sizing up whether Aimee is telling the truth.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: If you change your mind... Aimee turns back around. Sutter shrugs. He and Cassidy head to the dance floor. Once they’re dancing:

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: She looks nice.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: She does.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: What’s with the flask? You’re not turning her into a lush are you?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You wanna dance or lecture me about Aimee?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: I wanna dance. Sutter spins her. They’re getting more comfortable now. Sutter accidentally bumps into another guy who looks pissed. Sutter apologizes. Song over, Sutter bows to Cassidy who curtsies back. Then they part ways. He watches her walk over to Marcus before turning to walk back to Aimee. Sutter kisses her cheek as he sits down next to her. Aimee smiles. Seems like she means it. Then again, might be the alcohol talking. Sutter takes her hand and holds it at the table. He looks around the room. Sees Ricky and Beth having fun. Sees Shawnie twirling on the dance floor with her date. Everything he sees makes him happy.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Amazing, isn’t it, Aim? All these kids. Dressed up, dancing, singing, falling in love... This is our night! St. Patrick’s Day for the young. (beat) Do you realize -- right now, this moment, this is as young as we’re ever gonna be. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it. The spectacular now. (beat) God, I love these people. The song ends and a new one begins, slower, more romantic. Sutter grabs Aimee and gestures to the floor. This time she doesn’t resist. They dance. her head on Sutter’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I can’t dance like Cassidy.
dance She puts You dance like Aimee. And that’s perfect. We stay with them a few beats. A nice moment. - LATER. Sutter and Aimee walk out of the main room and out onto the grounds.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: We're gonna miss the King and Queen.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Fuck that. We’re all Kings and Queens tonight.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: (starting to slur) That’s right! I’m the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: And I’m your King.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I need to sit down. They take their seat on a bench. The stars are out tonight. It’s beautiful. Neither says a word for a second. Aimee starts to but stops herself.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You have any more?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah, here.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: (drinks) I’ve been thinking... about the summer. My sister said she could get me a job at a book store.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: In St. Louis?  78.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: A book store’s perfect for you.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I know! And it’ll help pay for college.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Have you talked to your mom yet?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: No but I will.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: That’s excellent. I can’t think of anything better.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I can. (beat) Come with me.... Sutter doesn’t know what to say to that.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I’ve looked into it. You can take classes at the junior College. We’ll both get jobs downtown. In our free time we can go to Forest Park or hang out by the river. Have you ever seen the Mississippi? I’ve only seen pictures but it looks amazing.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (beat) Wow. That’s... that’s some plan. You've really done your homework.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Yeah. And best of all my sister says there’s tons of vacancies in her building cause of the economy and stuff. They’re not expensive at all. We could move at the end of June. You and me. Sutter remains dazed, silent.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Sutter... what do you think? Looking at Aimee, Sutter knows there’s only two possibilities. Break her heart right now -- or just go with it.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I think... that’s a terrific idea. Best I’ve ever heard.  79. Aimee embraces him. They kiss. We can tell what she can’t: Sutter is not convinced about any of this. - LATER. Sutter and Aimee walk back into the room. Aimee is ecstatic. Sutter looks pained now. The joy of the buzz completely sucked out of him. The prom itself seems to be equally pallid. The room has thinned out. The glitter is crumbling. The lame decorations are half on the ground. There’s no sign of Sutter’s friends. Depression threatening, Sutter makes his move.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous. Hops up on the riser and grabs the mic from the DJ.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Can I have everybody’s attention? The music stops. There’s a little feedback from the mic.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Come on people, let’s pick this party up. This is our night. Some people yell out “woo Sutter” etc. Aimee is by this point too drunk to shout. Others are clearly less enthusiastic.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: How bout I add a little class to the evening? (clears his throat) A 1 anda 2 and 1 2 3.. (sings) “You're nobody till somebody loves you. You're nobody till somebody cares.” Sing it with me. Sutter doesn’t remember the next line. The crowd starts to turn on him.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Da da da... shit. Um... “Head keeps spinning, go to sleep grinning, if this is just the beginning, my life will be beautiful!”

dialogues.speaker: SOMEONE IN THE CROWD
dialogues.text: Sit down!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You sit down. Dickhead.

dialogues.speaker: SOMEONE ELSE
dialogues.text: Go back to rehab!  80. Other kids start shouting too. Mr. Aster runs over to put a stop to it.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ASTER
dialogues.text: Alright Mr. Keely, that’s enough.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I’m just warming up.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ASTER
dialogues.text: I said that’s enough.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: This is our night, Mr. Asterhole, not yours. Some people cheer the dig at the teacher but not everyone.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ASTER
dialogues.text: That’s it, your prom’s over.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Fine. We’ll take this party elsewhere. Sutter drops the mic on the ground. Hops off the riser. Stumbles a little on the way down but covers it up well enough. He still thinks he’s under control but the stares from his classmates say otherwise. Sutter pays them no mind. Cassidy runs up to him.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: You have to take Aimee home.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Cass where you been?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: In the bathroom with your girlfriend. She passed out on the floor!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Ouch. Was it my singing?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: This is not a joke Sutter.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Ok, ok, I’ll take care of her.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: I don’t think you know how.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hey, this is none of your business, Cass.  81.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: It’s not about me. And it’s not about us. It’s about -

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Stop! Aimee comes out, walking at a bit of a tilt, covered in vomit, angry.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Get away from him. You’re not his boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: I was just trying to get him to --

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I know what you were trying to do. You were practically... dancefucking!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Whoa.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Aimee --

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Stay away from him, you fat bitch. At which point Aimee winds up and slaps Cassidy across the face, hard. But in the process, she loses her balance and falls onto the punch bowl table, crashing it to the floor. Cassidy looks at Sutter as if to say “look what you've done to her.” Sutter receives the look, brushes it off, and runs to Aimee’s aid.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Can you sit up? Are you cut? Come on, let’s get you up in this chair. He lifts her up, gently.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Don't be sorry. It’s the prom, things happen at the prom.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I’m such a mess.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You’re beautiful. Let’s get out of here. Sutter helps Aimee to her feet. She takes one step and vomits again onto the floor.  82. Anyone still watching the scene (which is most people) groan at the sight. Sutter sees Cassidy still giving him that look, the same one he got a thousand times as her boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: She’s just not used to partying so hard.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Cassidy, I’m sorry...

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: It’s OK.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: (starts crying) No, really...

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Take her home, Sutter.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I will. Come on, baby, you'll be alright. Everything’s gonna be alright. And with Cass watching, as he helps her out of the room:

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I love you, Sutter. I love you so much. And this is like a gunshot to Sutter. Of all the things to happen tonight, that one stings the most. BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: INT CLOTHING STORE
dialogues.text: Sutter rings up a customer -- Jason Doyle.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Nice-looking suit.

dialogues.speaker: JASON DOYLE
dialogues.text: Present from my pops. You should have seen him when I got into Dartmouth. Guy was in tears. Sutter doesn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: JASON DOYLE
dialogues.text: You pick a college?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Yeah.  83.

dialogues.speaker: JASON DOYLE
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: JASON DOYLE
dialogues.text: Nice. Go Gators.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: See ya around Jason. Once he’s gone, Bob appears in the doorway to the back room.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Sutter -- Bob gestures for Sutter to follow him into the back. Sutter does. Sits down in the desk across from him.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You've probably noticed we’re not too busy these days. And because of that... well, I can only keep one clerk. (Sutter nods, waits for it) You know I like you, Sutter. More importantly, the customers like you. So I think you should be the one I keep.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: That’s excellent, Bob. Thank you! You won’t regret it.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Hold on a sec. (beat) I’ve given this some hard thought, and the only way I can let you stay is if you promise me, 100 percent, that you’ll never come in here loaded again. Sutter is taken aback by this. He never thought Bob was on to him.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’m serious. Not even a light buzz. And if you do, one time, I’m gonna have to let you go. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Can you promise me, Sutter?  84. Bob looks Sutter in the eye. Sutter holds his gaze for a beat, then laughs to himself.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You've got me there, don’t you, Bob? You know I can’t promise that. Bob looks at Sutter, disappointed, hoping he’1ll reconsider. Knows he won’t.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I appreciate your honesty.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Of course, Bob. I’m always up front with you. Sutter, proud of himself, rises to shake Bob’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: It's been a pleasure working for you Sir. Bob stares at him a beat. Then shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I guess... if I was your dad, here’s where I’d give you a lecture or something... ‘bout what you’re doing to yourself.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You know what, Bob... If you were my Dad, you wouldn’t have to.

dialogues.speaker: EXT CLOTHING STORE
dialogues.text: Sutter leaves, loosening his tie on the way out. Feeling pretty good until:

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Can we talk to you for a minute? Cassidy stands on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Who’s we? She points to a parked car. Marcus and Ricky are inside. INT MARCUS’ CAR - CONTINUOUS Sutter sits next to Ricky in the back. Marcus and Cassidy are in the front. They all look at him.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Please tell me this isn’t one of those, ‘We’re worried about your drinking’ intervention type things.  85.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: No, Sutter. We know you better than that.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: It’s more like an Aimee Finecky intervention thing.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: You're hurting her, dude. Don’t you see that?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I’m hurting her? How am I hurting her?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: We never once saw her drink before. Now she’s gets drunk between classes. She’s hungover every morning --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Since when do any of you give a shit about Aimee?

dialogues.speaker: MARCUS
dialogues.text: That’s not the point --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Of course it is. You don’t know her. You look at her and see this little mouse who should keep quiet and hide in the corner, don’t you? Well I see more than that. I see someone whose dreams are as big as all of yours put together. Someone who can stand up for herself now. And do you know why? Cause of me. I did that.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: You think you’re some kind of hero?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Yes as a matter of fact --

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Fuck off, Sutter. You’re not a hero. You're just using her... to keep from dealing with your own shit.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Really. One girl gives you the time of day and now you’re an expert --

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Fuck you.  86.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Fuck you! Before push comes to shove:

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Guys. Cool it! (beat; to Sutter) Can we talk alone for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: EXT PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: Sutter and Cassidy lean against Sutter’s car. Silent at first.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: It’s a nice night.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I’ve had better.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: This was my idea. So don’t blame the guys. Look, we just want what’s best for Aimee.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: And that’s not me?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: It could be. Maybe. If you tried. Sutter stands there for a moment without saying anything. He watches some garbage get blown across the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: If you really have this vast knowledge about me and relationships, then you’d know I don’t need to break anything off. She’ll take care of that soon enough, just like you did.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: You think that was easy for me? Say what you want, but you’re the one who made it clear we didn’t have a future. And I get it. That’s you, that’s who you are. But Aimee’s different. You’re her whole world. She thinks there’s a future with you and there isn’t.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Yeah? What makes you so sure?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?  87.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I mean... maybe there is one. A future. Maybe in the Fall the two of us are moving in together.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: It’s all set. Her sister got us a place in St. Louis. Heading out right after graduation.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: You can’t be serious.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: As a heart attack. Just gave my two weeks notice to Bob. (beat; Cass is shocked) Guess you don’t know everything, do you Cass? And with that, Sutter (like Shane) flips the double bird to his friends and gets in the car. Cassidy watches him drive off, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: EXT HIGH SCHOOL
dialogues.text: Sutter and Aimee walk towards the parking lot. Some kids laugh and point. One shouts:

dialogues.speaker: CLASSMATE
dialogues.text: Puke-a-reena! Sutter wants to go get in that guy’s face but Aimee keeps him walking.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: It's ok. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Just come on. They get to his car and Aimee pulls out her flask.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You sure you wanna --

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: We're celebrating. (off his look) I did it. I talked to my mom.  88.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (surprised) What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I just walked in, shut off Nancy Grace, and I told her. It’s my life and I’m not going to let that stupid paper route get in the way.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: And it worked?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: It was ugly at first. She tried to guilt me into staying but I refused to back down. I just said, look, if I can afford it, I’m going and there’s nothing you can do about it.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: That’s amazing! I’m so proud of you!

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I’m proud of myself! Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (beat) Cheers. They drink.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Wow Aim, you're like my hero.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: It wasn’t so bad. You'll see.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: When you do it. Sutter looks away.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: We made a deal.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Aimee --

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You can do it Sutter. I know you can.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You don’t know her. She's...  89.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You can do it. Sutter isn’t so sure.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Repeat after me. “I want to call him, Mom.” “I want to motherfucking call him.” Sutter looks at Aimee. Aimee looks back. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: INT HOTEL LOBBY
dialogues.text: An elegant, upscale hotel downtown. Mary works behind the Front Desk checking in a customer. Sutter takes a deep breath and walks in through the automatic doors. Waits patiently for his Mom to finish. Mary sees him. This is a surprise. Beckons him over.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Nothing. I, uh, I want to ask you something.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What is it? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: It’s about Dad.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (not again) Sutter --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I just want to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: We've been over this. It’s not a good idea --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I don’t need a reason, do I?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Yes you do! He’s my father.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well I’m your mother and you live under my roof.  90.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I wish I didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (beat) I know that, Sutter, but that’s the way it is.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You can’t keep him from me. It’s not right.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (quiet but stern) Sutter... this is my job. We'll talk about it later, Ok? I have guests.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Mom, please --

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Enough! (to Guest) Hi, may I help you? The Guest looks at Sutter. Sutter looks at his Mom. Mary ignores him. A standoff. One that Sutter is not gonna win.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: No wonder he left you. And with that, Sutter grabs a handful of mints from the jar on the counter. Storms off.

dialogues.speaker: EXT SUBURBAN HOUSE
dialogues.text: Sutter sits on the patio with Holly, who, as usual, is overdressed for the occasion. Sutter watches with amusement as she fusses with food and drinks.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: How do you like the way we've relandscaped back here? Joe and I planted some --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: That's nice, yeah. So like I said on the phone, I wanted to talk to you about Dad.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Oh Sutter, why do you want to dredge that up?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Dredge? Come on, Holly. Dad’s not something you dredge. He’s great. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gl.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remember how he used to tell us stories out in the tent in the backyard?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: That was mostly you. I was a little old for stories by the time we got that tent.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Well, you remember our vacation in Mexico? He had us going up to people and asking ‘em ‘Where can we find the belt buckle museum?’ or ‘Why is there no artichoke ice cream?’ It was hilarious.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: It was embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: People thought it was funny. They loved us.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: They loved you because you were little and cute.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: But the guys loved you. They thought you were a hot little muchacha. Holly remembers, then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: He did know how to make friends, didn’t he?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Damn right he did. They sit in silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Do you know happened? Between him and Mom?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: He cheated on her.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: How do you know that? That’s her version.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: You think it’s a lie?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I’m not saying she’s lying. I’m saying there’s two sides to every story.  92.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Sutter --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Think about it. She won’t let us see him. Won't say where he is --

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Let’s talk about something else. How’s your friend, how’s Aimee?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: -- won’t even give us his number. You gotta admit, it’s suspicious. Holly’s face shows that she’s thinking about it.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I tried asking Mom but she refuses. That’s why I need your help. Would you call her for me? Find out where he is? (off her look) Please, Holl. Will you ask her?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: (beat, looks at Sutter) I don’t have to ask her. I know where he is. Sutter looks at her, expectantly. She goes inside for a moment. When she returns she hands Sutter a slip of paper. Sutter looks at a phone number, then at his sister. Psyched!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Thanks, Holl. Seriously. You’re the best! Sutter jumps up to go.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Sutter! (he turns, beat) Come by for lunch sometime. Ok?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I will. Promise! Holly watches him go, apprehensive. INT SUTTER’S HOME - DAY Sutter is alone. Miles Davis plays in the background. He fixes himself a drink. Downs it. Takes a deep breath. Then takes out a piece of paper on which there is a phone number. Sutter picks up the phone. He seems nervous. Dials. After a few rings a deep, masculine VOICE answers.  Sutter is 93.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (tentative) Um.... Dad?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I think you got the wrong --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: It’s me, Sutter. SUTTER’S DAD (0.S.) (perks up) Sutter!? No shit, kiddo! How you doing? You sound like a man now!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (smiling) Well, yeah. SUTTER’S DAD (0.S.) How are you?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I’m alright. SUTTER’S DAD (0.S.) Good. Good. You still playing baseball?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What? SUTTER’S DAD (0.S.) You were a heckuva pitcher back in the day. Small for your age but what an arm. overcome with emotion but he sucks it down.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You remember that? SUTTER’S DAD (0.S.) Sure, son, sure I do. Still throwing?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I, uh, no. Not really. SUTTER’S DAD (0.S.) How's your Mom and Holly doing?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: They’re good, Dad... Real good. SUTTER’S DAD (0.S.) That’s great. That’s... tremendous.  94. And then silence for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Listen, Dad, I, uh, I was thinking... could I come see you sometime...? SUTTER’S DAD (0.S.) Of course you can. Come on over! How’s Friday?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Oh, uh, really? SUTTER’S DAD (0.S.) Come by at like 3 o’clock. Maybe we’ll go to a game.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (cloud nine) That would be great. SUTTER’S DAD (0.S.) Tremendous. See you then --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hey, uh, Dad... where, um, where do you live? INT SUTTER’S CAR - DAY Sutter and Aimee speed down the highway, filled with excitement. Music on, windows down, feeling good. Sutter sips from the Big Gulp. Aimee looks through the recently released High School Yearbook.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: How much further is it?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Another three hours or so. (beat; sincere) Hey Aim... thank you.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t have done this without you. He grabs her hand. She holds his, touched. Smiles. Sutter looks at the road again. Anticipation building.

dialogues.speaker: EXT DAD'S HOME
dialogues.text: Sutter and Aimee pull into a parking area in front of a row of townhouses. The whole place looks very poorly cared for.  95.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (checking slip of paper) Here we are. (beat) I think I need that shot of vodka now. They take a couple of shots. Then a couple more. Sutter looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Ok. Let’s do it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT DAD'S DOORSTEP
dialogues.text: Sutter rings the doorbell. After a few moments he rings again. After the third ring the door opens. TOMMY KEELY, (late 40s) extremely handsome but in a worn, creased way.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Well, hello there. What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (confused) It's... me. Tommy stares blankly at him.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Sutter.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (realizing) Sutter! Hey! Oh, of course. Man, what am I thinking? I forgot you were coming. Good to see you buddy. Tommy shakes Sutter’s hand. No hug.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: And who is this striking young lady?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: This is Aimee. My girlfriend. Aimee, this is my Dad. He takes Aimee’s hand, then kisses it. She blushes.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Call me Tommy. You have immaculate taste in the ladies, don’t you? (winks at her) Just like his old man. Tommy smiles at Sutter. This is followed by an awkward silence. Tommy doesn’t yet invite them in.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Man it’s good to see you.  96.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You too Dad --

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Listen, I was on my way to meet some friends of mine but now that you’re here, let’s all go together. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (looks at Aimee; she shrugs) Um... ok.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Great. You take your car and follow me there. It’s just up the road. Come on. Tommy gets in his beat-up Wagoneer. Sutter and Aimee head back to the Mitsubishi. Once inside:

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Another shot of whisky, doctor?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Stat. INT LARRY’S - LATER A dark and dirty little bbq joint adjacent to the highway. The BARTENDER and some of the REGULARS greet Tommy when he enters, much like Sutter’s friends when they see him enter a room. After a few hello’s:

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Everybody... this here is my son, Sutter. Everybody welcomes Sutter with raised glasses and a few pats on the back. Tommy seems proud. Sutter and Aimee are elated. When they reach the end of the bar the bathroom door opens and out comes ROBERTA (45, short dress, trashy). Tommy is surprised to see her.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Well if it isn’t the most beautiful woman in this here entire state.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTA
dialogues.text: Last week you said the country.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Did I? Tommy smiles at her. Winks.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTA
dialogues.text: (beat) Aren’t you gonna introduce me to your friends?  97.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (realizing) Where are my manners? Roberta... I’d you to meet my son. The amazing Sutter Keely. And his ladyfriend Aimee. Sutter beams. Roberta moves right up to him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTA
dialogues.text: Get your good looks from your mother, did ya?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Ma‘am. Roberta kisses Sutter on the cheek and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (watching her go) Ain’t she somethin’? Let’s get some drinks! LATER. Tommy sits with Sutter and Aimee at a corner table. Sutter and Aimee drink beers. Nobody’s minding.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: .-- and after that I moved to Key West. You guys ever been down there? (they haven't) You don’t know what you’re missing. Key West, now that is the life, boy. Sunsets like a butterscotch sundae with swirls of strawberry mixed in, melting into the ocean. Everyone with a drink and a smile. Tommy grins, and so does Sutter.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Sounds perfect.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: It was. (beat) Wish you could have been there kiddo.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: So how come you left?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Ran out of dough is why. Would have stayed there forever if I could, believe me. Tommy looks in the direction of Roberta, who is sitting at the bar chatting with other men. His stare lingers there a bit.  98.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hey how bout some music?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: That’s a great idea. You take care of that. I’ll go get us a refill. Tommy gets up and walks over to the bar. Sutter goes to the jukebox with Aimee.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You OK?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Never better. She squeezes his arm and smiles back. Sutter finds exactly what he’s looking for on the jukebox. Dean Martin’s “Aint That a Kick in the Head” begins to play. They go back and sit down. ANGLE ON Tommy, new pitcher in hand. On his way back to the table, he stops and whispers something in Roberta’s ear. She eyes him flirtatiously. Tommy sits back down. Sutter smiles, expecting Tommy to react to the music. He doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (beat, proud) Dean Martin.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Don’t you like this song?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Eh, this was always your mother’s thing. This is news to Sutter. It’s a bit of a shock. His only response is to take a large drink of his beer.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: But it’s... fun. I can’t imagine Mom ever having fun --

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Your mother? Are you kidding? When we first got married... boy was she something. Nobody was more fun than that woman. Again, Sutter is stunned. And again Tommy is looking away at Roberta.  99.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: So... what happened?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (still looking away) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What happened... between you two? Now Tommy turns back around.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (takes another drink) Things don’t work out sometimes. Sutter processes. Aimee watches him, growing increasingly concerned. And then:

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You know she blames you for everything. Won’t even let us talk about you. Tommy does not seem the least bit surprised.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I defend you though. I always defend you.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Thanks, kiddo. I appreciate that. (beat) Wasn’t all my fault.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Right. There’s two sides to every story.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Damn straight.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: And whatever happened, she still shouldn't have kicked you out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Oh she didn’t kick me out.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I left. Sutter can’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I had to. I mean, I did want to be there for you. Man, did I ever want that. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You guys were more important to me than anything in the world. But... well... things between your mother and I just got to be so... uncool. Once she caught me with that -- (beat) Guess I wasn’t cut out to be a family man, not in the traditional sense anyway. Tommy laughs. The room is now spinning for Sutter. Tommy sees his face.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: You know how it is. One thing leads to another... the girls don’t mean anything.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Girls? Like, more than one?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Not like I kept a running tally. (beat) But hey, I don’t live in the past. I live in the now. That’s what it’s all about. Right, kid? Sutter looks like he might throw up. Tommy sees Roberta get up and leave the bar. Tommy jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I'll be right back. Settle the tab for me, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Um, sure.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Thanks bud. You're a miraculous marvel. And with that he heads outside. Sutter just watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Sutter...? But he’s just sitting there, staring out the window at Tommy, who’s now pressing up close to Roberta, whispering in her ear. She laughs and playfully pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Sutter. Sutter snaps back to attention. Opens his wallet to pay Tommy's bill. He only has a few bucks. He looks to Aimee with embarrassment.  101.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about it. Really.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Don’t be. Tommy comes back inside.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: (winks ) So Roberta’s had a few too many drinks. Think I’d better give her a ride home. If you know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Oh... Um... you want us to follow you?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: I got it covered. Won’t be more than an hour.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: But -- why don’t we come with you? We’re not doing any--

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: No need. You guys head on back to my place. I’ll be right there I promise. The bad feeling growing, Sutter tries one more time.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Dad, we came all this way... Tommy smiles at his son. Puts a hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: And I’m sure glad you did, kiddo... See you soon. EXT TOMMY’S DUPLEX - LATER Sutter and Aimee sit parked outside Tommy’s house. The rain is pounding down on the roof of the car. Sutter takes a big hit from his flask.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: It's getting pretty bad out. We should probably head back.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: It’s only been a few hours. We can wait -- Sutter angrily turns on the ignition, quickly pulls away.  102. INT. SUTTER’S CAR - LATER ANGLE ON SUTTER in the driver’s seat. The car is not moving. The only sound are the wipers sweeping back and forth. REVEAL what Sutter is looking at: his father, right back at the BBQ/bar. Tommy tips back the last of his beer and laughs at something one of his buddies said. BACK TO SUTTER. Frozen. Aimee doesn’t know what to say. Without a word, Sutter composes himself. Drives away. We stay with them in the car. The silence continues. The wipers keep sweeping. Sutter looks like he’s about to burst. Aimee watches him, expecting the explosion any moment. She puts on the radio, tuning until she finds a baseball game. They listen for a few moments. Sutter angrily turns it off. More silence. Sutter takes a long swig as he drives. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I’m sure he wanted to come back --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Aimee --

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: You saw her. She was in no condition to drive.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Please --

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: That’s probably what happened. If it wasn’t for her, he would have come right back.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Sure, and if he hadn’t cheated on mom then we’d still be a family and I'd be president of my Sunday school class and you and I would ride silver stallions to Pluto. This shuts her down. Sutter glances over, feeling bad for snapping. Takes a deep breath and another drink.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Maybe we caught him on a bad day...

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: And maybe that’s just who he is. Huh? Maybe he’s been like that since day one. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just a selfish, lowlife, motherfucking asshole! Sutter shakes his head in disgust at himself. Aimee stays silent. They listen to the rain pour down. Until:

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Sutter.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I love you. Sutter exhales. Not what he wants to hear right now.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Did you hear me? Sutter still won’t engage.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Stop saying that.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Because --

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I want you to hear it. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You’re wrong. Aimee bristles at this. But Sutter has been waiting to say it. Can’t stop now.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Come on, Aimee, you don’t love me. You’re just... drunk and you're... grateful... someone came along and showed interest in you.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Don’t say that, Sutter. Don’t try to mess this up --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Mess what up? What do you think this is? At which point a loud horn blares from an oncoming car.  104.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Watch out! All this time, the car has been swerving slowly into the other lane. Sutter quickly rights the wheel and the car fishtails in the other direction, the road slick and wet from the rain. With no seatbelt on, Aimee slips down into the floorboard as Sutter struggles to regain control. The car sideswipes a concrete abutment before Sutter is finally able to wrestle it to a stop in the high grass off to the left, facing the wrong way (passenger door closest to the highway). When the dust settles:

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: (peering up from the floor) Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Are you ok?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You’re asking me that? Jesus Christ, Aimee, no! I’m way fucking far from ok.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: (moving in for a hug) Thank god you’re not hurt.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (pushing her off) What is wrong with you?! I nearly killed you and you wanna hug me?

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I wanna make sure you’re --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You need to run, Aimee. You need to get as far away from me as you possibly can.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: They're right about me. Everyone’s right.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Sutter, what are you --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Get out of the car.  105.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: No! Sutter leans over and opens the passenger door.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Get out of the fucking car! Aimee doesn’t move. Tears start to fall from her eyes. She bites her lip and finally gets out. Aimee stands there. On the side of the road, the door still open.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Aimee, what are you sorr--? But he doesn’t get the rest of it out. An approaching car can’t see Aimee through the rain and the fog. She’s hit! Knocked off of her feet by the blow. Goes down hard. And everything changes. Sutter freaks, jumping out of the car, running as fast as he can to her side. Aimee lies in the grass, hair soaked, face caked in mud, blood dripping from her scalp. She isn’t moving.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Aimee, oh fuck, Aimee. What have I done? Sutter kneels over her. Afraid to touch her. Falling apart.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Please, God, don’t do this. Oh please, fuck. I’ll do anything. I swear. I’1l never drink again just don’t let her go. Finally Aimee opens her eyes. Seeing him, she still can’t help but smile. Then she collapses again.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Aimee!

dialogues.speaker: INT HOSPITAL
dialogues.text: Sutter waits, fidgeting, his right foot tapping nervously on the floor. Seems like he’s been there a while. Finally a DOCTOR (40s, serious) leaves Aimee’s room. In the BACKGROUND we see Aimee’s Mom sitting at Aimee’s bedside. The Doctor approaches Sutter.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: The bone fragments were only partially split so it doesn’t require surgery. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s the good news. The bad news is she suffered a minor concussion. There may be some dizziness so she should take it easy the next few days.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Yes sir. The Doctor puts down his chart and looks hard at Sutter.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: She didn’t say much about what happened. Sutter says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (beat) I'll give you a choice, kid. The cops or your parents?

dialogues.speaker: INT HOSPITAL
dialogues.text: Sutter waits. Through the glass of the room behind him we can see Sutter’s Mom arguing with the Doctor. The voices are muffled but he can hear clearly enough.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Her blood alcohol level was twice the legal limit and I’d be willing to bet his was too. Did you know where he was tonight, Mrs. Keely?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What gives you the right to talk to me like that?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I’m sorry if I sound harsh --

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me how to be a parent! I work 15 hours a day to support my family.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: A lot of moms work hard, Mrs. Keely, and their kids don’t drink and drive. Mary is silenced by this.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Your son is lucky. And so is his girlfriend. Not everyone gets a second chance. Mary doesn’t respond. Sutter hasn’t moved an inch.  107. INT MOM’S CAR - LATER They drive silently. We stay on them for a while. Sutter looks at his Mom. She looks straight ahead. A mixture of anger and guilt on her face. EXT/INT AIMEE’S HOUSE - DAY Sutter rings the doorbell. Aimee’s Mom answers and immediately hugs him. AIMEE’S MOM There he is! The hero!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) Hi Mrs. Finecky. Once inside Randi and Shane wave hello from the living room. Sutter waves back. AIMEE’S MOM Aimee’s in her room. Sutter leaves them and heads to Aimee’s room. INT AIMEE’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS Aimee’s on the bed, reading. Sutter enters and sits on the end of the bed. He looks at her in her cast.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Should we talk about it? Sutter’s face says he’d rather not.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I agree.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Aimee, I’m so sor -- She silences him with a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Let’s never speak of it again, ok? I don’t want anything getting in the way of St. Louis. She touches his face with her hand. Sutter looks pained.

dialogues.speaker: EXT CONVENIENCE STORE
dialogues.text: Sutter parks his car. Baseball game in the background. He’s about to go in to the 7/11 when out comes little Walter (from the first scene). Walter holds hands with his mother while sipping from a Big Gulp. Sutter stares at the image, unnerved.  108. FADE UP: “Pomp and Circumstance.” CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: EXT HIGH SCHOOL GRADUATION CEREMONY
dialogues.text: Where Aimee, still in a cast, grabs her diploma from the PRINCIPAL MCNULTY. She turns to the crowd, waves, and walks on, taking her seat on the lawn amongst the rest of the graduates. It’s a beautiful day and the grounds are packed with students and their families. A few more students are called to get their diplomas. There’s still no sign of Sutter. Is he graduating?

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Sutter Keely. There he is. Principal hands him the diploma. Students shout for him.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENTS
dialogues.text: Woo Sutter! Someone else shouts:

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT
dialogues.text: Cartwheel!

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER STUDENT
dialogues.text: Sing us a song! Sutter pretends he doesn’t hear them. He walks off. Aimee excitedly claps. On the way to his seat, Sutter opens the diploma folder a tiny bit. It’s empty. He’s not surprised. Closes it before anyone else can see. Sutter takes his seat. Aimee turns around to look at him. She’s never looked happier. LATER. Aimee and Sutter are away from the crowd. Aimee takes out a flask and spikes her drink. She’s about to do the same for Sutter but he stops her.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Really? Why not?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Think I’1l just drink on the weekends from now on.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: More for me. Aimee takes a drink. Sutter watches her.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Is your family here?  109.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I told them it was next week. Aimee laughs. Sutter can’t help but smile at her. Krystal, standing with her family, calls Aimee over.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: I should go say hi. Be right back. She runs off. Sutter remains, alone for a beat or two. And then:

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Hey there graduate.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Hey Cass.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: How you doing?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I’m good. You?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Ready for some news...? I’m not going to State anymore.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (surprised) You're staying here?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: Oh god no. I’m going with Marcus. California baby!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You're... really? Isn’t that a little... sudden?

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: We talked about it and we just... we’re doing it! Crazy, huh?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Well, that’s... that’s great.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: I know, it’s exciting! Like a whole new era in my life is beginning.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Very cool.

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: And you know what Sutter, if it wasn’t for you and Aimee, going off together, I don’t think we would have done it. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But now it feels, I don’t know, it just feels right. So thank you. Cassidy hugs him. Tight. Sutter is still surprised. Once she pulls away:

dialogues.speaker: CASSIDY
dialogues.text: You'll stay in touch, won’t you? You’ll write us from St. Louis.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
