dialogues.text: You got it. Cassidy leaves. Sutter is alone again. He looks at Aimee, taking pictures with her Mom. He looks at his shoes. Runs his fingers through his hair.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BUS STATION
dialogues.text: The bus to St. Louis is already boarding. Aimee waits to the side, suitcase in hand. She’s nervous. Her mood is sinking. She checks her watch. The last passenger boards.

dialogues.speaker: BUS DRIVER
dialogues.text: Miss.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: Just... two more minutes ok. The Driver gets back on the bus. Aimee is nervous for a few more beats. And then she just starts to cry. The sadness overwhelms her. And then, just as quickly, she stops crying. She takes a few breaths, wills herself to be brave, picks up the suitcase and boards the bus. As the doors close, and Aimee takes her seat, REVEAL Sutter has been watching this from a far. Tears in his eyes as well. The bus drives off in the distance. He watches it go. INT SUTTER’S CAR - DAY Driving. Trying not to be overcome with emotion. Silently convincing himself he’s done the right thing. And that he doesn’t need a drink. He drives by a very seedy looking dive bar. He keeps driving. He looks in the rearview mirror, the bar still in view, beckoning.

dialogues.speaker: INT SEEDY DIVE BAR
dialogues.text: The lowest of the low. Dank, dark, and dusty. Two thuggish MEN play pool on a wrinkled table. Sutter sits at the bar next to a rumpled DRUNK in his late 60s. The BARTENDER has a wispy goatee and is missing some teeth. They've all been there a very long time.  111.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Another round for the table. (BARTENDER nods) Thank you, Earl, thank you for serving me. This is better. Much, much better.

dialogues.speaker: RUMPLED DRUNK
dialogues.text: You're a good guy, Sutter.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: That’s what I think too. I agree. (to BARTENDER) What do you think? Was I wrong to let her go? Did I do the right thing?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: For you or for her? The question doesn’t get to hang for too long as the Drunk chimes in.

dialogues.speaker: RUMPLED DRUNK
dialogues.text: You had to! You had to save that girl.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: That’s what I did. I saved her.

dialogues.speaker: RUMPLED DRUNK
dialogues.text: You’re not wrong. You’re a hero. You’re a King!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: That’s right! You’re exactly right.

dialogues.speaker: RUMPLED DRUNK
dialogues.text: Look at you, Suther. What are you 19, 20?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I am 18 years old.

dialogues.speaker: RUMPLED DRUNK
dialogues.text: Beautiful. You got your whole life ahead of you.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: So do you, my man.

dialogues.speaker: RUMPLED DRUNK
dialogues.text: Not me. I’m old. My friends are gone. I’ve wasted all this time... Sutter flinches at the words for a second but is able to dismisses them.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: We're your friends.  112.

dialogues.speaker: RUMPLED DRUNK
dialogues.text: You are.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: RUMPLED DRUNK
dialogues.text: Thank you boy. Then let’s have a drink. To friendship. They toast. EXT SUTTER’S HOUSE - NIGHT Sutter’s Lancer takes the turn into the driveway too fast, crashing into the mailbox. Sutter exits the vehicle, leaving it half on the lawn.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (ce: damage) Shit. A light turns on inside the house. Mary comes outside, pulling a robe around herself.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What the hell? (seeing the mailbox) Sutter!? Sutter ignores her. Mom watches him stumble towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Have you been drinking? Sutter says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! We just went through this. The hell is wrong with --

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What do you care?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: You don’t care about me. You’ve never cared about me.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Sutter. (beat) Look, I’m sorry, ok? I know I haven't always been there for you and I’m gonna try harder --  113.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: It’s cause I remind you of him.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: That’s why you hate me. That’s why you can’t stand to look at me.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (stunned) Sutter! How can you say that?! You’re my son!

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I'm his son too. We’re exactly the same.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (beat) You’re wrong... You’re nothing like him. Sutter won’t listen. He storms past her and walks inside. Mom follows. She walks right past Sutter and into the kitchen. Sutter, about to climb the stairs, hears his mom rummaging in the other room. He stops. Mom reappears, handing him a piece of paper. CU: the paper has an address on it.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Go to him. Then you’ll see. Sutter looks at the slip.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I thought you didn’t --

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I was trying to protect you from -- (beat) I was wrong. Take this. Go see him. See for yourself how different you are. Sutter is stunned by this.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: I've already been. Now it’s Mom’s turn to be surprised.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Holly gave me his number and... we drove there last week... You were right. He's... you were right all along.  114. And Mary knows what Sutter is really saying.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You're not your father. Sutter tries to hold himself together but he can’t look his mother in the eye. Mary grabs him into a hug. Sutter allows it but doesn’t respond, not yet.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (beat) Sutter listen to me. That man... that man’s never loved anyone but himself. His heart is this big. But you... you love everybody. You’ve got the biggest heart of anyone I know. Sutter’s hit hard by this. Starts to lose his composure.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Remember 3rd grade, when Ricky was on crutches for a month. Who carried his books every day? Or when you were 10 and Rosemary Clark lost her mother. You invited her to live with us, said I’d be her new mom. Remember that? You've always been so special, Sutter. That’s why everyone loves you.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: Nobody loves me Mom.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You’re wrong. And now Mom is crying too. Holds him tighter.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You hear me, Sutter? You’re wrong. And finally Sutter hugs back. He closes his eyes as they hold each other. Over her shoulder, we see him crumble the slip of paper in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A COMPUTER SCREEN. “Describe a challenge, hardship or misfortune you have experienced in your life.” Sutter sits at his desk. Eyes still wet. Reads on. “What have you learned from this and how has it prepared you for the future?” Sutter stares at it a beat. And then he starts to write.  115. SUTTER’S VOICE My name is Sutter Keely and I’m 18 years old... Compared to other kids, I haven’t had that many hardships. Not really. Shit’s happened... Sutter pauses, deletes “shit” and replaces it.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Stuff’s happened, sure, stuff always happens... but the real challenge in my life, the real hardship... is me. It’s always been me. ANGLE ON SUTTER, deciding whether to continue. He does. SUTTER’S VOICE As long as I can remember, I’ve never NOT been afraid.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Sutter behind the wheel. He doesn’t look afraid. And then the Big Gulp in hand. He takes a sip. SUTTER’S VOICE Afraid of failure. Of... letting people down. Hurting everyone. Getting hurt. SERIES OF SHOTS: Cassidy angry with him, Sutter not knowing why; Sutter catching Cassidy with Marcus on the couch; the first time he sees Aimee; SUTTER'’S VOICE I thought if I kept my guard up, focused on other things, other people... SERIES OF SHOTS: Sutter bringing Walter to his mom; hooking Ricky up with Beth; coaching Aimee to shout and curse at the party;

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: .».-if I couldn’t even FEEL it... well then no harm would come to me. SERIES OF SHOTS: Sutter drinking excessively. Goofing off. Jumping into the hot tub. Singing at the prom. Reaction shots of pity from his classmates.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I was wrong. Not only did I shut out the pain, I shut out everything. The good and the bad. SERIES OF SHOTS: peacefully in bed with Aimee; Holly reaching out to him; the disappointment on Bob’s face as he has to let Sutter go; Aimee’s bus pulling away; Sutter and Mom hugging.  116.

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Until there was nothing. BACK ON Sutter at his computer... SUTTER'’S VOICE I’m not gonna do that anymore. SERIES OF SHOTS: the future. Sutter empties his flask in the sink; Sutter uses a lighter to set the pennant ablaze, watches it burn; Sutter sitting at the kitchen table with Holly and Mom. Saying grace. All together. SUTTER'’S VOICE It’s fine to just “live in the now.” But the best part about “now” is -- there’s another one tomorrow. I promise not to waste that one. Sincerely, Sutter Keely.

dialogues.speaker: EXT COLLEGE CAMPUS
dialogues.text: A beautiful, sparkling day on a beautiful college campus. SUTTER'’S VOICE P.S. I don’t know if this was due a long time ago. Probably was. But that’s fine. The truth is... Aimee comes out of a classroom looking confident, secure. She says goodbye to friends and walks down the steps. SUTTER’S VOICE It may be too late for this essay.. And then she sees him. Standing there. Waiting for her. And he’s cleaned up too. Steady on his feet. Haircut. SUTTER’S VOICE «.-It’s not too late for me. In his hand is Aimee’s purple ski jacket.

dialogues.speaker: AIMEE
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: SUTTER
dialogues.text: (beat) You forgot your coat. And before we ever know what happens next: BLACK.
